questions.text: A 45-year-old patient underwent a kidney transplant and presents with signs of graft dysfunction two weeks post-operation. A biopsy is performed, and staining reveals the presence of a specific complement factor in the peritubular capillaries. Which of the following complement factors is most indicative of this acute humoral (antibody-mediated) rejection?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) C4d

 

  • C4d deposition in the peritubular capillaries is a hallmark of acute antibody-mediated rejection (AMR) in organ transplantation, particularly in kidney transplants.
  • It is part of the classical complement pathway and indicates the presence of donor-specific antibodies (DSAs) binding to the graft endothelium, leading to complement activation.
  • The detection of C4d in biopsy samples helps confirm the diagnosis of humoral rejection, guiding appropriate management to reduce immune-mediated damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. C5a: C5a is an anaphylatoxin involved in the recruitment of neutrophils and other inflammatory cells. While it plays a role in the inflammatory response, it is not specifically used as a marker for antibody-mediated rejection in transplant settings.

 

Option B. C3b: C3b is an opsonin that tags pathogens for phagocytosis and is involved in complement activation, but its presence is not a specific marker of humoral rejection in transplant biopsies.

 

Option C. C3d: C3d is a product of C3 cleavage and can be associated with complement activation. While C3d may be present in various immune responses, it is less specific for humoral rejection compared to C4d, which directly indicates classical complement activation in the context of transplant rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • C4d is a key marker of acute humoral (antibody-mediated) rejection in organ transplants, particularly kidneys, as it indicates the presence of donor-specific antibodies and complement activation through the classical pathway.

questions.text: Which of these procedures is done for correction of abnormal curvature of the penis (chordee)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nesbit operation

 

  • If the penis is of adequate length, it is possible to plicate the tunica albuginea on the side opposite to the maximum curvature.
  • The plication can be done by Nesbit’s technique.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Grayhack shunt: The Grayhack shunt involves creating a connection between the corpora cavernosa and the saphenous vein and is used for treating refractory ischemic priapism when other shunting techniques have failed.

 

Option C. Rovsing operation: Deroofing of polycystic kidney disease

 

Option D. Buccal mucosa flap urethroplasty: Done for urethral stricture

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nesbit technique is used for correction of abnormal penile curvature like in Peyronie’s disease.

questions.text: Which technique is best for measuring current flow through a single ion channel?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Patch clamp

 

  • Patch clamp is the ideal method to study the current flow across a single ion channel.
  • This technique allows for the precise measurement of ionic currents through individual ion channels by isolating a small patch of membrane.
  • It is particularly useful for understanding the function of ion channels under various physiological and pathological conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voltage clamp: This technique is used to measure the ionic currents across a cell membrane by holding the membrane potential constant. However, it is typically used for studying the collective current through multiple ion channels rather than individual ones.

 

Option C. Iontophoresis: This technique involves the movement of ions through tissues using an electric current and is more relevant for drug delivery rather than measuring ion channel currents.

 

Option D. Microelectrode recording: While microelectrode recording can measure electrical activity in neurons, it lacks the precision required to isolate and measure currents from a single ion channel, unlike the patch clamp technique.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The patch clamp technique is the gold standard for studying the activity of individual ion channels, allowing for the detailed analysis of ionic currents at the single-channel level.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of increased abdominal girth, bloating, and fatigue. He has a long-standing history of heavy alcohol consumption, averaging more than 30 units per week since he was 16. On physical examination, he has gynecomastia, visibly red palms, and a distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave. Laboratory studies show elevated liver enzymes, a prolonged prothrombin time, and low serum albumin. Given his clinical presentation, which pathophysiological mechanism most likely explains the development of gynecomastia and palmar erythema in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reduced estrogen metabolism

 

  • The patient's long-standing history of heavy alcohol consumption suggests the development of chronic liver disease, likely cirrhosis.
  • In cirrhosis, the liver's ability to metabolize hormones, including estrogen, is significantly impaired.
  • This reduced estrogen metabolism leads to higher circulating levels of estrogen, which can cause secondary effects such as gynecomastia (due to the increased stimulation of breast tissue) and palmar erythema (a result of vascular changes associated with elevated estrogen).
  • These signs are characteristic physical findings in patients with chronic liver disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytokine release: While cytokine release is involved in the inflammatory response seen in liver disease, it does not directly account for the gynecomastia and palmar erythema. These symptoms are more specifically linked to hormonal imbalances rather than inflammation alone.

 

Option B. Decreased hepatic protein synthesis: Chronic liver disease leads to decreased production of proteins like albumin and clotting factors, resulting in hypoalbuminemia and coagulopathy. However, this is not the direct cause of gynecomastia or palmar erythema.

 

Option C. Increased portal venous pressure: Increased portal pressure is associated with complications like ascites, splenomegaly, and varices. It does not directly cause gynecomastia or palmar erythema; these findings are more related to hormonal changes due to impaired liver metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chronic liver disease, particularly cirrhosis, can lead to impaired estrogen metabolism.
  • This hormonal imbalance is responsible for the development of gynecomastia and palmar erythema, classic signs seen in patients with advanced liver disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the clinic seeking advice on family planning options. During the session, the clinician uses a structured guide for the discussion, ensuring that the patient's concerns are addressed, providing accurate information, and helping her make an informed decision. Which structured method is most likely being used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GATHER approach

 

  • The GATHER approach is a structured counselling method commonly used in contraceptive counselling.
  • It stands for Greet, Ask, Tell, Help, Explain, and Return/Refer, and it guides healthcare providers through a step-by-step process to ensure that patients receive personalized and comprehensive information.
  • It helps ensure that the patient’s needs and concerns are addressed while providing appropriate and accurate information about various contraceptive options, allowing the patient to make an informed choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Respectful maternal care: This focuses on ensuring dignity, respect, and compassionate care during childbirth but is not specific to the structured approach of contraceptive counselling.

 

Option C. Counselling for cervical cancer screening: This is related to educating women about screening tests like Pap smears and HPV tests but is not specifically associated with the GATHER approach.

 

Option D. PPIUCD counselling: This is specific to providing information about postpartum intrauterine contraceptive devices, but the structured GATHER approach is broader and applies to general contraceptive counselling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The GATHER approach is a structured counselling technique used to provide comprehensive and personalized contraceptive counselling, ensuring that the patient’s concerns are addressed and accurate information is given to help them make informed decisions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with difficulty swallowing and hoarseness of voice. During the physical examination, when the posterior pharyngeal wall is touched with a tongue depressor, she exhibits a gag reflex.  Which of the following cranial nerves is responsible for the sensory component of the gag reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cranial Nerve IX

 

  • The gag reflex is a protective reflex involving the sensory and motor innervation of the pharynx.
  • Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal nerve) provides the sensory innervation to the posterior third of the tongue and the pharyngeal mucosa, which is stimulated during the gag reflex.
  • When the posterior pharyngeal wall is touched, Cranial Nerve IX senses the touch and sends sensory signals to the brainstem. The motor response of the gag reflex is then mediated by Cranial Nerve X (Vagus nerve), causing the elevation of the palate and pharyngeal contraction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus nerve): Incorrect. While Cranial Nerve X mediates the motor response of the gag reflex (i.e., palate elevation and pharyngeal contraction), it does not provide the sensory input that initiates the reflex.

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal nerve): Incorrect. Cranial Nerve XII controls motor function of the tongue muscles, but it is not involved in the sensory or motor components of the gag reflex.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory nerve): Incorrect. Cranial Nerve XI primarily innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, playing no role in the gag reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gag reflex involves the sensory limb carried by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) and the motor limb carried by the Vagus nerve (CN X).
  • Stimulating the posterior pharyngeal wall activates Cranial Nerve IX, leading to a reflexive pharyngeal contraction through Cranial Nerve X.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman with a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and heart failure presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath over the past 3 days. She denies chest pain or palpitations. On examination, her temperature is 99.5°F, blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg, pulse is irregular at 135/min, and oxygen saturation is 88% on room air. Jugular venous distention and bilateral wheezing are noted. An ECG is taken and shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Correct underlying electrolyte abnormalities

 

  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is commonly associated with chronic lung diseases like COPD and is often triggered by hypoxemia or electrolyte disturbances.
  • The management of MAT primarily involves correcting the underlying causes, such as hypoxemia, hypokalemia, or hypomagnesemia, rather than using traditional antiarrhythmic medications.
  • Addressing these triggers can help stabilize the arrhythmia and improve overall clinical status.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Synchronized cardioversion: Cardioversion is not indicated in MAT as it is not effective in arrhythmias arising from multiple atrial foci, unlike atrial fibrillation or flutter.

 

Option B. Intravenous diltiazem: While rate control may be beneficial, diltiazem is not the first-line treatment in MAT since treating the underlying condition (e.g., electrolyte imbalances or hypoxemia) is more effective.

 

Option D. Intravenous amiodarone: Amiodarone is used for various arrhythmias, but in MAT, it is less effective compared to correcting the precipitating factors like electrolyte disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary management of multifocal atrial tachycardia involves correcting the underlying causes such as hypoxemia and electrolyte imbalances, especially in patients with chronic pulmonary conditions.

choices.text: Encodes a cell surface receptor for growth factors

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman with a significant family history of early-onset breast and ovarian cancer undergoes genetic screening. The results reveal a pathogenic variant in the BRCA1 gene. Which of the following best describes the primary role of the BRCA1 gene in cellular function?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Repairs double-strand DNA breaks

 

  • The BRCA1 gene is critical in maintaining genomic stability by facilitating the repair of double-strand DNA breaks through homologous recombination, a high-fidelity repair mechanism.
  • Mutations in the BRCA1 gene result in impaired DNA repair, leading to an accumulation of genetic damage, which increases the risk of breast and ovarian cancers.
  • This function distinguishes BRCA1 as a key player in preventing malignancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stimulates cell cycle progression: BRCA1 is not directly involved in stimulating cell cycle progression. Instead, it acts more as a safeguard, halting cell cycle progression to allow for DNA repair when damage is detected.

 

Option B. Regulates apoptosis: Although BRCA1 is indirectly involved in the regulation of apoptosis as a response to DNA damage, its primary function is DNA repair, not directly inducing or regulating apoptosis.

 

Option D. Encodes a cell surface receptor for growth factors: This function is more characteristic of genes like HER2, which encode growth factor receptors involved in cell signalling. BRCA1 is primarily involved in the DNA damage response and repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene crucial for repairing double-strand DNA breaks through homologous recombination. A mutation in BRCA1 disrupts this repair process, increasing susceptibility to breast and ovarian cancers.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after experiencing trauma to the right groin area while playing sports. On physical examination, the physician lightly strokes the inner thigh, leading to a reflex contraction of the cremaster muscle, causing elevation of the right testis. Which of the following spinal nerve roots is responsible for this cremasteric reflex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) L1, L2

 

  • The cremasteric reflex is mediated by the genitofemoral nerve, which originates from the L1 and L2 nerve roots.
  • This reflex involves the afferent limb from the ilioinguinal nerve (L1) and the efferent limb via the genitofemoral nerve (L1-L2).
  • Stroking the inner thigh activates sensory fibers, leading to contraction of the cremaster muscle and resulting in elevation of the testis on the same side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8, T9: Incorrect. The T8-T9 nerve roots are primarily associated with the upper abdominal muscles and the cutaneous innervation of the upper abdominal wall, not with the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option C. L3, L4: Incorrect. While L3 and L4 are involved in patellar reflexes and leg innervation, they do not contribute to the genitofemoral nerve or the cremasteric reflex.

 

Option D. S1, S2: Incorrect. The S1 and S2 nerve roots are typically involved in lower extremity reflexes such as the Achilles reflex and do not play a role in the cremasteric reflex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The cremasteric reflex is mediated by the L1 and L2 spinal nerve roots, specifically involving the genitofemoral nerve.
  • This reflex is tested by gently stroking the inner thigh, leading to contraction of the cremaster muscle and elevation of the testis.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old child presents with suspected hearing loss. The otolaryngologist wants to conduct objective tests to evaluate the child's hearing ability. Which of the following tests are considered objective methods for assessing hearing?

 

  1. Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA)
  2. Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)
  3. Pure tone audiometry
  4. Tympanometry
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2, and 4

 

Objective hearing tests do not rely on the patient's subjective responses and can provide accurate assessments, especially in young children or patients who may not reliably respond to subjective tests like pure tone audiometry.

 

The objective tests include:

 

  • Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (BERA): This test measures electrical activity in the brainstem in response to sound stimuli. It is particularly useful in diagnosing hearing loss in infants and young children, as it does not require active participation from the patient.
  • Otoacoustic emissions (OAE): This test measures sounds that are generated by the inner ear (cochlea) in response to an auditory stimulus. The presence or absence of these emissions can help assess cochlear function, making it useful for newborn hearing screenings.
  • Tympanometry: This test measures the movement of the tympanic membrane (eardrum) in response to changes in air pressure in the ear canal. It helps evaluate middle ear function and detect conditions such as middle ear effusion or eustachian tube dysfunction.

 

Pure tone audiometry is a subjective test, as it requires the patient's active response to hearing different tones at varying frequencies and intensities, and thus is not considered an objective measure.

 

Other Options:

 

3: Incorrect, as pure tone audiometry is not an objective test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Objective hearing tests such as BERA, OAE, and tympanometry are essential tools for diagnosing hearing loss in children, especially when patient cooperation may be limited.
  • These tests provide reliable information about the auditory pathway and middle ear function without requiring subjective feedback from the patient.

choices.text: Presence of a non-human reservoir
Dormant or latent phase in human hosts
Transovarian transmission of the virus in mosquitoes
Poor community sanitation and hygiene

questions.text: In India, the dengue virus persists during inter-epidemic periods through a direct man-mosquito-man transmission cycle. Which of the following mechanisms best explains the virus's survival during these periods of low human infection?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Transovarian transmission of the virus in mosquitoes

 

  • Transovarian transmission is a mechanism through which the dengue virus is passed from an infected female mosquito to its offspring through its eggs.
  • This allows the virus to persist in mosquito populations even during periods when there is a reduction in human cases.
  • This method of survival helps maintain the presence of the virus in regions like India during the inter-epidemic periods, ensuring that the virus can re-emerge when conditions are favorable for another outbreak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of a non-human reservoir: Incorrect. Unlike some other arboviruses, the dengue virus does not rely on non-human animal reservoirs for its survival. The primary vector is the Aedes mosquito, and the cycle is primarily between humans and mosquitoes.

 

Option B. Dormant or latent phase in human hosts: Incorrect. The dengue virus does not establish a latent phase in humans. Once infected, humans can carry the virus for a limited period during the acute phase of the illness, but they are not long-term carriers of the virus.

 

Option D. Poor community sanitation and hygiene: Incorrect. While poor sanitation can contribute to increased breeding sites for mosquitoes and higher transmission rates, it does not explain how the virus survives during periods when human infection rates are low. The transovarian transmission in mosquitoes is the key factor in virus persistence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The dengue virus survives during the inter-epidemic periods through transovarian transmission within mosquito populations, where infected female Aedes mosquitoes pass the virus to their offspring.
  • This ensures the persistence of the virus even when human infection rates are low.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with muscle cramps and fatigue after moderate physical activity such as running or playing sports. Laboratory studies reveal elevated creatine kinase levels during episodes of muscle pain. Additionally, blood tests reveal mild chronic anemia and signs of red blood cell breakdown.  Further analysis shows reduced activity of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) in muscle cells and red blood cells. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tarui's disease

 

  • Tarui's disease, or Glycogen Storage Disease type VII, is caused by a deficiency in phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1), an essential enzyme in glycolysis.
  • The deficiency affects both muscle cells and red blood cells.
  • During physical activity, muscle cells cannot adequately use glucose for energy, leading to muscle cramps, fatigue, and elevated creatine kinase due to muscle damage.
  • Additionally, because PFK-1 is also involved in glycolysis in red blood cells, the deficiency can cause hemolysis, leading to mild chronic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. McArdle disease: This condition is characterized by a deficiency in muscle glycogen phosphorylase, leading to muscle cramps and exercise intolerance. However, McArdle disease does not involve hemolytic anemia, which is a distinguishing feature of Tarui's disease.

 

Option C. Pompe disease: Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease type II) is due to a deficiency in acid alpha-glucosidase and primarily affects cardiac and skeletal muscles, leading to cardiomegaly, muscle weakness, and respiratory failure. It does not present with exercise-induced muscle cramps and is not associated with PFK-1 deficiency.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease type I) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, leading to severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hepatomegaly. It is not associated with muscle cramps or hemolytic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tarui's disease (Glycogen Storage Disease type VII) is caused by a deficiency of phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) in muscle cells and red blood cells, leading to exercise-induced muscle cramps, myoglobinuria, and hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with chronic joint pain and reduced mobility in his knee. Imaging reveals degenerative changes in the knee joint, prompting a biopsy of the joint cartilage. The histopathological image of the cartilage is shown below. Based on the microscopic appearance, which of the following types of cartilage is most likely present?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) White fibrocartilage

 

  • The image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes, characteristic of white fibrocartilage.
  • Fibrocartilage is found in structures that require tensile strength and shock absorption, such as the intervertebral discs, pubic symphysis, and menisci of the knee.
  • The dense collagenous matrix helps resist compression and shear forces, making it ideal for supporting weight and maintaining joint integrity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Articular hyaline cartilage: Incorrect. Hyaline cartilage is characterized by a smooth, glassy matrix with scattered chondrocytes in lacunae and minimal visible collagen fibers. It forms the articular surfaces of most joints, providing a smooth surface for joint movement. The image does not show the typical homogeneous appearance of hyaline cartilage.

 

Option B. Non-articular hyaline cartilage: Incorrect. Non-articular hyaline cartilage is similar in appearance to articular hyaline cartilage but is found in locations like the trachea and nasal septum. The given image shows collagen fiber bundles, which are not characteristic of hyaline cartilage.

 

Option D. Yellow cartilage: Incorrect. Yellow cartilage, also known as elastic cartilage, contains elastic fibers in addition to collagen. It is found in the external ear, epiglottis, and eustachian tube. The image does not show the characteristic elastin network seen in yellow cartilage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • White fibrocartilage is characterized by dense collagen bundles and is found in structures that require high tensile strength, such as the menisci and intervertebral discs.

choices.text: Beckwith Wiedmann syndrome; wt 2 gene (11p15.5)

questions.text: A mother brings her 2-year-old child with complaints of his large tongue which is not completely accommodated in his mouth as shown in the image and enlargement of only one side of the body and limbs. On further evaluation earlobe creases were noted. Identify the syndrome the baby is presenting with and its gene responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beckwith Wiedmann syndrome; wt 2 gene (11p15.5)

 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) is characterized by features such as macroglossia (large tongue), hemihyperplasia (enlargement of one side of the body), and earlobe creases or pits.
  • These features are indicative of an overgrowth disorder present from birth.
  • BWS is associated with mutations or alterations in the WT2 gene locus on chromosome 11p15.5, which regulates growth.
  • Other features of BWS may include abdominal wall defects, hypoglycemia in infancy, and an increased risk of tumors such as Wilms' tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. WAGR syndrome; WT1 gene (11p13): WAGR syndrome includes Wilms' tumor, Aniridia (absence of the iris), Genitourinary abnormalities, and mental Retardation. It is associated with deletions in the WT1 gene on chromosome 11p13, not 11p15.5, and does not typically present with macroglossia or hemihyperplasia.

 

Option B. Denys-Drash syndrome; WT1 gene (11p13): Denys-Drash syndrome is characterized by Wilms' tumor, pseudohermaphroditism, and glomerulopathy leading to kidney failure. It is linked to mutations in the WT1 gene. Unlike BWS, it does not present with macroglossia or hemihyperplasia.

 

Option D. Down syndrome (Trisomy 21): Down syndrome is characterized by features such as a single palmar crease, sandal gap, upslanting palpebral fissures, and hypotonia. It results from an extra copy of chromosome 21 (Trisomy 21). It does not present with macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, or earlobe creases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is a congenital overgrowth disorder characterized by features like macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, and ear creases.
  • It is associated with genetic changes in the WT2 gene locus on chromosome 11p15.5, leading to abnormal regulation of growth.

questions.text: Which of the following types of neurons innervates the intrafusal fibers of the muscle spindle?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gamma neuron

 

  • Gamma motor neurons innervate the intrafusal fibers within muscle spindles.
  •  These neurons regulate the sensitivity of muscle spindles to stretch, ensuring that the spindle can adjust to changes in muscle length.
  •  Activation of gamma neurons causes contraction of intrafusal fibers, maintaining tension and sensitivity to muscle stretch, which is essential for proprioception and fine-tuning muscle activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beta neuron: Beta motor neurons primarily innervate extrafusal muscle fibers and have a role in muscle contraction. They do not play a significant role in directly modulating the sensitivity of the muscle spindle.

 

Option C. Alpha neuron: Alpha motor neurons innervate extrafusal muscle fibers, which are responsible for the actual contraction of muscles. While crucial for muscle movement, they do not directly influence the sensitivity of the muscle spindle.

 

Option D. Delta neuron: Delta neurons (A-delta fibers) are sensory neurons that transmit pain and temperature sensations rather than motor control. They do not have a role in the regulation of muscle spindle function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gamma motor neurons provide the motor supply to intrafusal muscle fibers of the muscle spindle, allowing adjustment of spindle sensitivity to muscle stretch, which is crucial for proprioception.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is diagnosed with a gynecological malignancy that has a risk of lymphatic spread. She is scheduled for a sentinel lymph node biopsy to evaluate potential metastasis. In which of the following cancers is this procedure most useful for determining lymph node involvement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carcinoma vulva

 

  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most useful in patients with early-stage carcinoma of the vulva.
  • It helps determine if the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes without the need for a more extensive lymph node dissection, thereby reducing morbidity.
  • The sentinel lymph node is the first lymph node to which cancer cells are likely to spread from the primary tumor.
  • If this node is negative for cancer, it is likely that the remaining lymph nodes are also free of cancer, allowing for less invasive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoma cervix: Although lymph node involvement is significant in carcinoma of the cervix, the use of SLNB is not the standard of care for this cancer type. More extensive lymph node dissection or imaging studies are typically used for staging.

 

Option B. Carcinoma endometrium: Sentinel lymph node biopsy can be used in certain cases of endometrial cancer, especially in early stages, but it is not as well-established as it is in vulvar cancer. Traditional staging procedures often involve a more extensive lymph node dissection.

 

Option D. Carcinoma vagina: SLNB is not typically used in the management of vaginal cancer. This cancer type is rare, and the standard approach usually involves other methods for assessing lymph node involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) is most valuable in early-stage carcinoma of the vulva to assess lymph node involvement while minimizing the need for extensive lymph node dissection.
  • It helps determine the spread of cancer to lymph nodes and guides further treatment.

choices.text: Increased renin release and aldosterone secretion
Elevated atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) due to central volume expansion
Suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after falling through the ice while skating on a frozen lake. He presents with confusion and disorientation. His temperature is 93.2°F, pulse is 120/min, and respirations are 22/min. Physical examination reveals cold, pale extremities, and numbness of the fingers. His blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Laboratory results show mildly elevated serum creatinine, normal electrolyte levels, and an increased urine output over the next several hours. Further evaluation reveals a decrease in serum antidiuretic hormone (ADH) levels. Which of the following additional findings would be most consistent with the underlying physiological mechanism of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Elevated atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) due to central volume expansion

 

  • In hypothermia, peripheral vasoconstriction occurs as a compensatory response to conserve heat, which leads to an increase in central blood volume.
  • The body perceives this volume shift as an excess, leading to increased atrial stretch and subsequent release of atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP).
  • The increase in ANP contributes to natriuresis and diuresis.
  • Additionally, the perceived central volume expansion causes a decrease in ADH secretion, further promoting urine production, known as cold-induced diuresis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased renin release and aldosterone secretion: Increased central blood volume and elevated ANP typically suppress the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Thus, renin release and aldosterone secretion would be decreased, not increased.

 

Option C. Enhanced proximal tubular sodium reabsorption: Increased ANP promotes natriuresis by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the collecting ducts rather than enhancing proximal tubular reabsorption.

 

Option D. Suppression of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis: Hypothermia triggers a stress response, leading to activation, not suppression, of the HPA axis. This response is aimed at increasing glucocorticoid production to manage metabolic demands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In hypothermia, cold-induced diuresis is driven by an increase in central blood volume due to peripheral vasoconstriction.
  • This leads to elevated ANP levels, suppression of ADH, and increased urine production.
  • Understanding these interrelated physiological changes is crucial in managing hypothermic patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is being evaluated for metabolic concerns, and during the assessment, the clinician is comparing the metabolic characteristics of various body tissues. When discussing the energy production of the lens, the clinician emphasizes that the respiratory quotient (RQ) is distinct due to its predominant metabolic process. What is the respiratory quotient of the lens?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1

 

  • The respiratory quotient (RQ) of the lens is 1, which indicates that the lens primarily metabolizes glucose through anaerobic glycolysis.
  • The RQ of 1 is characteristic of carbohydrate metabolism, which means that the volume of carbon dioxide produced is equal to the volume of oxygen consumed.
  • Since the lens relies predominantly on glycolysis due to its avascular nature, glucose is its primary energy source.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The respiratory quotient (RQ) of 1 for the lens indicates that it primarily relies on carbohydrates for energy production.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not a contraindication for the use of osmotic diuretics?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cerebral edema

 

  • Cerebral edema is an indication, not a contraindication, for the use of osmotic diuretics such as mannitol.
  •  Osmotic diuretics can reduce intracranial pressure by drawing water out of the brain tissue into the bloodstream, which helps decrease cerebral swelling and pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary edema: Osmotic diuretics can exacerbate pulmonary edema by increasing intravascular volume, which can worsen respiratory distress. Therefore, they are contraindicated in this condition.

 

Option B. Acute renal failure: Osmotic diuretics may be contraindicated in acute renal failure because they require functioning kidneys to eliminate the excess fluid and can potentially worsen fluid overload if the kidneys are not functioning adequately.

 

Option C. Active cerebral bleeding: Osmotic diuretics are contraindicated in patients with active cerebral bleeding, as they can increase blood flow to the brain and potentially worsen the bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osmotic diuretics are indicated for conditions like cerebral edema to reduce intracranial pressure.
  • They are contraindicated in conditions like pulmonary edema, acute renal failure, and active cerebral bleeding due to the risk of worsening fluid overload or exacerbating bleeding.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with persistent headaches and a progressive decrease in hearing. She undergoes an MRI of the brain, which is shown below. Based on these findings, which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neurofibromatosis type 2

 

  • The MRI of image shows bilateral cerebellopontine angle masses, which are characteristic of vestibular schwannomas.
  • Vestibular schwannomas, especially when bilateral, are highly suggestive of Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • NF2 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the presence of bilateral vestibular schwannomas, meningiomas, and other CNS tumors.
  • The presence of these findings in a young patient with decreased hearing points strongly towards this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis typically presents with cortical tubers, subependymal nodules, and renal angiomyolipomas. It does not typically present with bilateral vestibular schwannomas, making this answer incorrect in the context of the presented imaging and symptoms.

 

Option C. Neurofibromatosis type 1: NF1 is more commonly associated with neurocutaneous manifestations such as café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, and optic gliomas. It does not typically involve vestibular schwannomas, especially not bilaterally.

 

Option D. Sturge-Weber syndrome: This condition is characterized by a port-wine stain and leptomeningeal angiomas leading to seizures and neurological deficits. It is not associated with vestibular schwannomas or findings in the cerebellopontine angle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bilateral vestibular schwannomas seen on brain imaging are pathognomonic for Neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2).
  • NF2 is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by multiple central nervous system tumors, including bilateral vestibular schwannomas, which can lead to hearing loss and other neurological symptoms.

questions.text: A public health consultant is evaluating the staffing structure of rural sub-centers in India to ensure they meet the recommended guidelines for primary healthcare delivery. She finds that one of the historical committees emphasized that each sub-center should be equipped with one male health worker and one female health worker to provide balanced care to the community. Which of the following committees made this specific recommendation to enhance the accessibility and quality of healthcare in rural areas?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Kartar Singh Committee

 

Kartar Singh Committee (1973):

 

  • Also known as ‘Committee on Multipurpose Workers under Health and Family Planning’
  • ANMs to be replaced by ‘Female Health Workers’; Basic health workers, Malaria surveillance workers, Vaccinators, Health education assistants and family planning health assistants be replaced by ‘Male Health Workers’
  • 1 PHC for 50,000 population, 15–16 subcentres each for 3,000–3,500 population
  • Each subcentre be staffed by team of one male and one female health worker
  • 1 Male Health Supervisor per 3–4 male health workers and 1 Female Health Supervisor per 4 female health workers
  • Lady Health Visitors be designated as Female Health Supervisors
  • Doctor in charge of PHC should have overall charge of supervisors and health workers in his area

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bhore Committee: Health Survey & Development Committee
  • Mudaliar Committee: Health Survey & Planning Committee
  • Jungalwallah Committee: Committee on Integration of Health Services
  • Kartar Singh Committee: Committee on MPWs under Health & Family Planning

choices.text: To examine the posterior nasal cavity
To visualize the larynx and vocal cords
To remove foreign bodies from the ear canal

questions.text: A physician uses the instrument shown in the image during a clinical examination. Which of the following is the primary use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To visualize the larynx and vocal cords

 

  • The instrument shown is a laryngeal mirror. It is primarily used for indirect laryngoscopy to visualize the larynx, including the vocal cords, epiglottis, and surrounding structures.
  • The mirror is gently placed at the back of the throat, and the reflection helps the physician view the laryngeal area without the need for invasive procedures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To examine the posterior nasal cavity: This procedure is typically done using a post-nasal mirror, which is smaller and angled differently to access the back of the nasal cavity.

 

Option C. To remove foreign bodies from the ear canal: This requires specialized ear instruments like ear forceps or an ear curette, not a laryngeal mirror.

 

Option D. To perform nasal septal surgery: Surgical procedures on the nasal septum require surgical tools like septal elevators or nasal speculums, not a laryngeal mirror.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A laryngeal mirror is used for indirect visualization of the larynx and vocal cords, allowing clinicians to assess the structures of the throat without invasive procedures.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with progressive changes in her right eye, including blurred vision and an abnormal pupil position. After slit-lamp examination, the patient is diagnosed with Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome. Which of the following findings is not typically associated with ICE syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cataract

 

  • Cataract is not typically associated with Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome.
  • ICE syndrome is characterized by changes primarily affecting the cornea, iris, and the angle structures of the eye.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Corectopia: Displacement of the pupil is a classic feature of ICE syndrome and is due to abnormal contraction of the iris tissue.

 

Option C. Iris cysts: Although less common than other features, iris cysts can be seen in ICE syndrome due to irregularities in the iris stroma.

 

Option D. Iris atrophy: Iris atrophy is a common feature of ICE syndrome and often appears as progressive thinning and loss of iris tissue, resulting in changes in pupil shape and appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Iridocorneal Endothelial (ICE) syndrome is a rare ocular condition characterized by corectopia, iris atrophy, and corneal endothelial abnormalities.
  • The exact mechanism is unknown, however there appears to be a component of abnormal corneal endothelium that proliferates onto the iris forming a membrane that then obstructs the trabecular meshwork, leading to iris distortion.
  • Nodule formation can also occur when the abnormal corneal endothelium causes contractions around the iris stroma.
  • Herpesvirus DNA has been identified in some patients following keratoplasty, suggesting the possibility that herpes simplex virus may induce the abnormal endothelialization in the anterior chamber angle and on the surface of the iris.
  • Cataracts are not a typical feature of ICE syndrome, and distinguishing these findings is essential in recognizing and managing this rare disorder effectively.

questions.text: Based on the graph provided, which type of enzyme kinetics is most likely demonstrated in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Michaelis-Menten Kinetics

 

  • The graph displays a hyperbolic curve, which is characteristic of enzymes following Michaelis-Menten kinetics.
  • In this type of enzyme reaction, as the substrate concentration increases, the reaction velocity (v) rises rapidly until it reaches a maximum velocity (Vmax), beyond which increasing the substrate concentration does not significantly increase the reaction rate.
  • The Michaelis constant (Km) represents the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of Vmax, providing insight into the enzyme's affinity for its substrate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cooperative Binding: Cooperative binding typically results in a sigmoidal (S-shaped) curve, not a hyperbolic one. This type of curve is seen with enzymes or proteins like hemoglobin, where substrate binding increases the affinity for subsequent substrate molecules.

 

Option C. Allosteric Activation: Allosteric enzymes often display sigmoidal curves due to changes in enzyme conformation upon binding of an allosteric activator. The provided graph lacks the S-shape characteristic of allosteric enzyme activity.

 

Option D. Sigmoid Curve: The graph in the question is hyperbolic, not sigmoidal. Sigmoidal curves are seen in cooperative enzyme binding, where the initial binding of the substrate alters the affinity of the enzyme for additional substrate molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Michaelis-Menten kinetics is characterized by a hyperbolic relationship between reaction velocity and substrate concentration, where Vmax represents the maximum rate of the reaction, and Km indicates the substrate concentration at which the reaction velocity is half of Vmax.
  • This model is typical for many enzymes under steady-state conditions.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of high-grade non-Hodgkin lymphoma begins chemotherapy. Within 24 hours, he develops nausea, vomiting, and muscle weakness. Laboratory studies reveal hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia and elevated uric acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely underlying pathology?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tumor lysis syndrome

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) occurs when rapidly dividing cancer cells are lysed, releasing intracellular contents into the bloodstream.
  • This leads to hyperkalemia (due to potassium release), hyperphosphatemia (from cell breakdown), and secondary hypocalcemia (due to phosphate binding calcium).
  • Elevated uric acid levels result from the breakdown of purines.
  • The symptoms of nausea, vomiting, and muscle weakness, along with these laboratory findings, are classic indicators of TLS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute tubular necrosis: While acute tubular necrosis (ATN) can cause renal dysfunction and elevated creatinine levels, it does not typically cause the specific combination of electrolyte imbalances (hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hypocalcemia) seen in TLS. ATN would also not directly cause hyperuricemia in the context of rapid tumor cell breakdown.

 

Option C. Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH): SIADH typically leads to hyponatremia due to water retention and is not associated with the hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, or hyperuricemia characteristic of TLS. SIADH is not a common consequence of chemotherapy for hematologic malignancies like lymphoma.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia of malignancy: Hypercalcemia of malignancy is often seen with certain cancers, but it is associated with elevated calcium levels, not hypocalcemia as seen in TLS. It also does not present with hyperphosphatemia and hyperuricemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumor lysis syndrome is characterized by the rapid release of intracellular contents into the blood following the destruction of malignant cells, leading to hyperkalemia, hyperphosphatemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperuricemia.
  • This condition is often triggered by chemotherapy in patients with high-grade malignancies, making close monitoring essential.

questions.text: A 32-year-old forensic expert is called to investigate the suspicious death of a newborn found in a remote area near a community health center. The body is partially decomposed, and the primary concern is to determine whether the newborn had been alive at birth. The forensic expert decides to use several tests that are historically known to help distinguish live birth from stillbirth. Which of the following tests is not used to determine live birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gettler’s test

 

Gettler's test is historically used to determine the level of chloride concentration in the heart blood to distinguish between freshwater and saltwater drowning, not to assess whether a birth was live. This test does not help in determining live birth and is therefore not relevant in scenarios where the determination of live versus stillbirth is necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ploucquet’s Test: This test is used to determine live birth by checking whether the lungs of the deceased infant float in water, suggesting the infant breathed air (i.e., was born alive).

 

Option B. Fodere’s Test: Similar to Ploucquet’s, this test also examines lung flotation but includes additional examination of lung tissue under a microscope to confirm air inhalation.

 

Option D. Wreden’s test: This test involves examining the middle ear to determine live birth. During fetal life, the middle ear contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue, which disappears and is replaced by air after live birth. If air is found in the middle ear, it supports the idea that the newborn was alive and had taken a breath.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tests like Ploucquet’s, Fodere’s, and Wreden’s are commonly used to assess whether a newborn was alive at birth by evaluating the lungs or middle ear. Gettler’s test, used to determine drowning, is not relevant in assessing live birth.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with confusion and lethargy. Her history is significant for a recent episode of gastroenteritis, which led to decreased oral intake. Blood tests reveal significantly elevated ammonia levels. Which of the following substrates of the TCA cycle is most likely decreased as a result of hyperammonemia, contributing to its neurotoxicity?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) α-Ketoglutarate

 

  • Hyperammonemia causes a shift in the balance between glutamate and glutamine in the brain, leading to the consumption of α-ketoglutarate.
  • Ammonia is detoxified in the brain by combining with glutamate to form glutamine, a process that is catalyzed by glutamine synthetase.
  • This reaction depletes α-ketoglutarate, an essential substrate in the TCA cycle.
  • The loss of α-ketoglutarate results in impaired energy production in neurons, contributing to the neurotoxic effects of ammonia and leading to symptoms such as confusion and lethargy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Succinyl CoA: Succinyl CoA is a TCA cycle intermediate but is not directly affected by the elevated levels of ammonia. The reduction of α-ketoglutarate due to ammonia-induced conversion of glutamate to glutamine occurs upstream of succinyl CoA.

 

Option C. Fumarate: Fumarate is downstream in the TCA cycle and is not directly influenced by hyperammonemia. The neurotoxicity of hyperammonemia is more closely related to the reduction of α-ketoglutarate.

 

Option D. Oxaloacetate: While oxaloacetate is a key intermediate in the TCA cycle, it is not the primary substrate affected by elevated ammonia levels. The depletion of α-ketoglutarate due to its role in glutamine synthesis is the central issue in hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hyperammonemia leads to the depletion of α-ketoglutarate in the brain as ammonia is detoxified through its conversion to glutamine.
  • This depletion disrupts the TCA cycle, reducing energy production in neurons and contributing to the neurotoxic effects of elevated ammonia levels, such as lethargy and confusion.

questions.text: A baby assessed at 5 minutes after birth had blue extremities and irregular gasping respiration. Heart rate was 40/min, and there was a grimace with some flexion of extremities. APGAR score for this newborn is _______.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5

 

  • The APGAR score in this baby is 5, based on the following criteria:
  • Color: Blue extremities (acrocyanosis) = Score 1
  • Heart Rate: 40 beats/min (less than 100/min) = Score 1
  • Reflex Irritability: Grimace when stimulated = Score 1
  • Muscle Tone: Some flexion of extremities = Score 1
  • Respiratory Effort: Irregular gasping respiration = Score 1
     
  • The total APGAR score is 5.
  • The APGAR score is assessed at 1 minute and 5 minutes after birth.
  • It evaluates five objective signs: Appearance (Color), Pulse (Heart Rate), Grimace (Reflex Irritability), Activity (Muscle Tone), and Respiration (Respiratory Effort). Each parameter is scored from 0 to 2, with 2 being the best score.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The APGAR score is used to quickly assess the health of a newborn immediately after birth, evaluating Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.
  • A score between 0-3 indicates the need for immediate resuscitation, while 4-6 suggests moderate difficulty, and 7-10 indicates a generally healthy newborn.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents with a painless ulcer on his penis that has been present for 2 weeks. He also has painless inguinal lymphadenopathy. The patient reports unprotected sexual activity and is concerned about a sexually transmitted infection. Serologic testing is performed. Which of the following statements about syphilis are true?

 

  1. VDRL test detects antibodies.
  2. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is IgE mediated.
  3. In primary and secondary syphilis, the treatment preferred is penicillin.
  4. RPR is done for CSF.
  5. Treponema pallidum can be easily cultivated in artificial culture media.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 3

 

Statement 1. VDRL test detects antibodies: This statement is correct. The Venereal Disease Research Laboratory (VDRL) test is a nontreponemal test used to detect reagin antibodies produced in response to cellular damage due to Treponema pallidum. It is used for screening purposes.

 

Statement 3. In primary and secondary syphilis, the treatment preferred is penicillin: This is also true. The treatment of choice for primary and secondary syphilis is benzathine penicillin G, which is highly effective at eradicating the infection and preventing complications. It is recommended for all patients, including those with penicillin allergy, for whom desensitization is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2. Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is IgE mediated: This statement is incorrect. The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is an inflammatory response occurring after the start of syphilis treatment (often with penicillin), characterized by fever, chills, and myalgia, and is not IgE-mediated. It occurs due to the release of endotoxins from dying spirochetes.

 

Statement 4. RPR is done for CSF: This is incorrect. The RPR (Rapid Plasma Reagin) test is a nontreponemal test used for serologic screening of syphilis in the blood, not for cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) testing. VDRL is the preferred test for CSF analysis in suspected neurosyphilis.

 

Statement 5. Treponema pallidum can be easily cultivated in artificial culture media: This statement is false. Treponema pallidum, the bacterium causing syphilis, cannot be grown in artificial culture media. It is highly fastidious and requires specialized conditions to be studied.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Syphilis is diagnosed using nontreponemal tests such as VDRL and RPR for screening.
  • The preferred treatment for primary and secondary syphilis is benzathine penicillin G.
  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a common inflammatory response to treatment but is not IgE-mediated. Treponema pallidum cannot be cultured in artificial media, and RPR is not used for CSF analysis.

choices.text: Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC)
Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC)
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC)
Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with severe abdominal cramps, initial watery diarrhea, followed by grossly bloody diarrhea. The parents deny any fever, and there is a concern for possible hemolytic-uremic syndrome. Which strain of Escherichia coli is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC)

 

  • The patient’s presentation of severe abdominal cramps, initial watery diarrhea, followed by grossly bloody diarrhea with little or no fever is consistent with Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) infection.
  • The specific strain O157 is often associated with this presentation, which may also lead to hemolytic-uremic syndrome (HUS).
  • The pathogenesis involves the production of a verocytotoxin (Shiga toxin), which inhibits protein synthesis in host cells, leading to epithelial damage in the colon and bloody diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC): Typically causes watery diarrhea, cramps, and low-grade fever in travellers and infants. It affects the small intestine and does not cause bloody diarrhea or HUS.

 

Option B. Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC): Causes dysentery-like illness with fever, cramping, and watery diarrhea that progresses to scant, bloody stools. It involves the large intestine, but fever is usually present, and the bloody diarrhea is not as prominent as in EHEC.

 

Option C. Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC): Causes copious watery diarrhea with fever, nausea, vomiting, and mucus-filled stools in infants. It is mainly associated with small intestine involvement and does not typically present with bloody diarrhea or cause HUS.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of swelling in her face, lips, and tongue. She denies difficulty breathing but mentions a tingling sensation in her mouth. She recently started taking a new antihypertensive medication. On physical examination, there is marked facial and lip swelling without urticaria or rash. Her vital signs are stable, and there is no evidence of anaphylaxis. Laboratory tests show normal serum tryptase levels. Which of the following pathophysiological mechanisms most likely explains this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Increased bradykinin levels

 

  • The patient's symptoms suggest angioedema, a known side effect of certain antihypertensive medications, particularly angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACE inhibitors).
  • ACE inhibitors lead to increased levels of bradykinin because they inhibit the enzyme responsible for bradykinin breakdown.
  • Elevated bradykinin levels result in increased vascular permeability and fluid leakage into the tissues, causing swelling.
  • This type of angioedema typically presents with sudden onset of facial and lip swelling without urticaria and is not mediated by histamine or mast cell activation, as evidenced by normal serum tryptase levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Histamine release: Histamine release is associated with allergic reactions, often presenting with urticaria, pruritus, and, sometimes, anaphylaxis. The absence of these symptoms and the normal serum tryptase levels make histamine release unlikely in this scenario.

 

Option C. Mast cell activation: Mast cell activation, as seen in allergic reactions or anaphylaxis, leads to histamine and other mediator release, resulting in urticaria and potentially respiratory symptoms. This patient's presentation lacks these characteristics, and normal serum tryptase levels further rule out mast cell involvement.

 

Option D. Autoimmune reaction: Autoimmune reactions typically involve a gradual onset and may present with systemic symptoms. Angioedema from ACE inhibitor use is a more acute, bradykinin-mediated event, unrelated to autoimmune mechanisms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Angioedema associated with ACE inhibitors is mediated by increased bradykinin levels, leading to sudden swelling without urticaria.
  • Recognizing this mechanism is crucial for appropriate management, which includes discontinuing the offending medication.

choices.text: A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2
A-1, B-4, C-3, D-2
A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate kit to use for the symptom mentioned?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

  • A. Lower abdominal pain: Correct Kit: 4. Yellow, Kit 6. This kit is used for lower abdominal pain, typically associated with conditions like pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). It includes Cefixime, Metronidazole, and Doxycycline, targeting common pathogens involved in PID.
  • B. Urethral discharge: Correct Kit: 1. Grey, Kit 1. Kit 1 is used for symptoms like urethral discharge, indicative of gonorrhea or chlamydia infections. It contains Azithromycin and Cefixime, effective against these pathogens.
  • C. Non-herpetic genital ulcer: Correct Kit: 3. White, Kit 3. Kit 3 is used for non-herpetic genital ulcers, such as those caused by syphilis or chancroid. It includes Azithromycin and Penicillin.
  • D. Vaginal discharge: Correct Kit: 2. Green, Kit 2. Kit 2 is recommended for vaginal discharge, which can result from bacterial vaginosis or candidiasis. It contains Secnidazole and Fluconazole to treat these infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The National Aids Control Organization (NACO has provided color-coded kits for the syndromic management of sexually transmitted diseases:

choices.text: Timolol
Oral acetazolamide
Dorzolamide
Dipivefrine

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman is seen for a routine eye examination. She has a history of open-angle glaucoma and has been using glaucoma eye drops for the past 15 years to control her intraocular pressure. Her current intraocular pressures are well maintained at 17 mm Hg in both eyes. On examination, you note the presence of black pigments deposits on the lower tarsal conjunctiva bilaterally. Which of the following medications is most likely causing this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dipivefrine

 

  • Dipivefrine is a prodrug of adrenaline (epinephrine) that is occasionally used in the treatment of glaucoma.
  • One of the side effects of dipivefrine is the formation of adrenochrome, an oxidation product of adrenaline that can result in black deposits in the conjunctiva.
  • Although this medication is not commonly used nowadays, such deposits are a known side effect of its oxidation.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Timolol: This beta-blocker is widely used in glaucoma treatment but does not produce black pigmented deposits on the conjunctiva.
 

Option B. Oral acetazolamide: This carbonic anhydrase inhibitor is taken systemically to lower intraocular pressure but does not cause conjunctival pigmentation.
 

Option C. Dorzolamide: A topical carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that also does not lead to black conjunctival deposits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dipivefrine, a prodrug of adrenaline, can lead to black conjunctival deposits due to the formation of adrenochrome. Recognizing medication side effects, particularly with older anti-glaucoma medications, is essential for managing patients who present with unusual ocular findings after prolonged treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is most likely not innervated by the superior gluteal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piriformis

 

  • The superior gluteal nerve (L4-S1) innervates the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae muscles, which are involved in hip abduction and stabilizing the pelvis during walking.
  • The piriformis muscle, however, is innervated by the nerve to the piriformis (branches of S1 and S2).
  • Therefore, any muscle dysfunction not related to these three muscles suggests the involvement of a muscle like the piriformis, which has a different innervation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tensor fasciae latae: Incorrect. This muscle is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve and contributes to hip abduction and internal rotation. It is not the muscle excluded from innervation by this nerve.

 

Option B. Gluteus minimus: Incorrect. The gluteus minimus is supplied by the superior gluteal nerve and assists in hip abduction and internal rotation. It is innervated by the superior gluteal nerve, making it an incorrect choice.

 

Option D. Gluteus medius: Incorrect. The gluteus medius is also innervated by the superior gluteal nerve and plays a key role in stabilizing the pelvis during walking and hip abduction. This makes it the wrong choice as well.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The superior gluteal nerve provides innervation to the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae, but not the piriformis, which is supplied by the nerve to the piriformis.

choices.text: Upper part of right inferior lobe

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of dysphagia due to a recent stroke is admitted to the hospital after aspirating food during a meal. He is found lying supine when the aspiration occurs. A chest X-ray reveals consolidation in one of the lobes of the lung. In the supine position, which of the following lobes is most likely affected by the aspiration in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper part of right inferior lobe

 

  • When aspiration occurs in a supine patient, the upper part of the right inferior lobe is most commonly affected.
  • This is due to the anatomical structure of the right main bronchus, which is shorter, wider, and more vertical than the left main bronchus, making it more susceptible to aspirated materials.
  • In the supine position, the posterior segments of the right upper lobe and superior segments of the right lower lobe are the most gravity-dependent areas, and thus more likely to collect aspirated material.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right superior lobe: Although the right main bronchus is the most common site for aspiration, in the supine position, the superior segments of the lower lobe are more likely to be affected than the superior lobe.

 

Option B. Right middle lobe: The middle lobe may be affected by aspiration in certain positions, like when sitting or standing, but is less commonly impacted in the supine position.

 

Option D. Lingula: The lingula is part of the left lung and thus is not typically involved in aspiration in the supine position, as the right lung's anatomy makes it more prone to aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a supine patient, aspiration is most likely to affect the upper part of the right inferior lobe due to the anatomy of the right main bronchus.
  • Understanding the gravity-dependent regions of the lungs is crucial for identifying potential areas of aspiration-related consolidation on imaging studies.

choices.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
High weight skeletal traction
Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision, complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

 

  • Hip dislocation, particularly posterior hip dislocation, is a common injury following high-energy trauma like motor vehicle accidents.
  • In a posterior hip dislocation, the femoral head is displaced from the acetabulum (typically posteriorly) but remains within the joint capsule.
  • Closed reduction is the initial treatment for a hip dislocation, where the joint is manually realigned without making an incision.
  • This should be performed as soon as possible (ideally within 6 hours) to reduce the risk of complications such as avascular necrosis of the femoral head.
  • After performing the closed reduction, hip stability should be assessed.
  • If the reduction is successful and the hip remains stable (i.e., the joint remains in place without further dislocation or instability), conservative management with monitoring may be sufficient.
  • Indications for closed reduction include a straightforward dislocation where there is no associated fracture of the acetabulum or femoral head, and the hip joint is stable after reduction.
  • Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability is the correct next step because it involves addressing the dislocation and assessing whether the hip joint is stable after realignment.
  • If the hip is stable, further intervention may not be necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. CT and 3D reconstruction: CT and 3D reconstruction are typically used for evaluating complex fractures, especially acetabular fractures or femoral head fractures. CT scans provide detailed information about the bone anatomy and fracture patterns, especially in complex pelvic injuries. However, if the issue is a dislocation without significant fracture involvement, the immediate need is for closed reduction to relieve pain and restore normal joint function. The CT scan would only be necessary if there is a concern for fractures of the acetabulum or femoral head that are not visible on plain x-rays.

 

Option C. High weight skeletal traction: Skeletal traction is typically used for certain types of long bone fractures, particularly femoral shaft fractures, where it is used to realign the bones and provide stability while the fracture heals. It can also be used for pelvic fractures or for certain complex fractures, but it is not commonly used for managing hip dislocations. After a hip dislocation, the main focus is on closed reduction and stabilization of the joint.

 

Option D. Open reduction and posterior pillar of acetabulum reconstruction: Open reduction is required when closed reduction fails or when the dislocation is associated with a complex fracture (such as an acetabular fracture) that cannot be addressed non-surgically. A posterior pillar of the acetabulum reconstruction refers to a specific surgical procedure for addressing fractures involving the posterior part of the acetabulum. However, if the dislocation is not associated with a complex fracture, surgical reconstruction (open reduction) is generally not required immediately. Only if there is a significant fracture of the acetabulum or the femoral head would surgery become necessary after the initial dislocation management.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first step in managing a hip dislocation (likely posterior dislocation in this case) is to perform a closed reduction.
  • Following this, the stability of the joint should be assessed to determine if further intervention is required.

choices.text: Radical cholecystectomy with lymphadenectomy with chemotherapy

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with abdominal discomfort and weight loss. An ultrasound shows a mass in the gallbladder. Further imaging confirms a 2.5 cm tumor confined to the gallbladder with no invasion into surrounding structures, but lymph nodes near the bile duct are enlarged. A diagnosis of gallbladder adenocarcinoma is made. What is the most appropriate treatment at this stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Radical cholecystectomy with lymphadenectomy with chemotherapy

 

  • The staging and treatment of gallbladder cancer are determined based on tumor size, invasion into surrounding structures, and lymph node involvement. This patient’s tumor is 2.5 cm, confined to the gallbladder, and shows evidence of lymph node involvement, which indicates at least operable stage disease. For gallbladder cancer with local lymph node involvement, the best treatment option is radical cholecystectomy with lymphadenectomy, which involves removing the gallbladder along with surrounding tissues, including the cystic duct, portions of the liver, and regional lymph nodes. Adjuvant chemotherapy may be given. This offers the best chance of survival in cases of locally advanced but resectable disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation with regular follow-up: This is not appropriate for gallbladder cancer, especially when the tumor is larger than 2 cm and there is lymph node involvement. Early-stage gallbladder cancer (T1a) might be managed with simple cholecystectomy, but more advanced stages require more aggressive management.

 

Option B. Cholecystectomy with adjuvant chemotherapy: This may be considered for very early-stage gallbladder cancer confined to the mucosa (T1a). However, for larger tumors with lymph node involvement, radical surgery with lymphadenectomy is necessary.

 

Option D. Palliative chemotherapy and radiation: Palliative care is reserved for unresectable or metastatic gallbladder cancer (e.g., distant metastases). This patient’s cancer is likely resectable, making radical surgery a better option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radical cholecystectomy with lymphadenectomy with chemotherapy is the standard treatment for gallbladder cancer that is locally advanced but resectable, particularly when there is lymph node involvement.

questions.text: This Radiographic Image could be a risk factor for:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kienbock's disease

 

  • Kienbock's disease is a condition that affects the lunate bone in the wrist, leading to avascular necrosis.
  • This occurs when the blood supply to the lunate is compromised, resulting in bone death.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Trauma: Previous wrist injuries can disrupt blood flow.
    • Anatomical Variations: Certain wrist structures can predispose individuals to this condition.
    • Repetitive Stress: Activities that involve repetitive wrist motions may increase risk.
  • On imaging, you may see a sclerotic lunate with varying degrees of flattening, cyst formation, and eventual collapse of the bone, indicating avascular necrosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Kohler's Disease: Kohler's disease is a rare condition affecting the navicular bone in children, typically ages 2 to 9. It involves avascular necrosis, but unlike Kienbock’s, it usually has a good prognosis. Primarily occurs in children. Some familial predisposition might exist. X-rays will show a flattened, sclerotic navicular bone. The condition is self-limiting and usually resolves without significant intervention.

 

 

Option C. Wartenberg Syndrome: Wartenberg syndrome, also known as Wartenberg's sign, is characterized by pain and sensory disturbances due to compression of the superficial branch of the radial nerve. It can lead to numbness or tingling on the back of the hand and is often associated with wrist injuries or conditions that cause swelling. Wrist injuries or repetitive strain can compress the nerve. Conditions that lead to edema can predispose individuals. This condition does not typically show specific changes on standard radiographs, as it is more about nerve entrapment rather than bony changes.

 

 

Option D. Preiser's Disease: Preiser's disease is similar to Kienbock's in that it involves avascular necrosis, but it specifically affects the scaphoid bone. It occurs when there is insufficient blood supply to the scaphoid, often following a fracture. A history of scaphoid fracture is a significant risk. Variations in blood supply can predispose some individuals. X-rays may initially show a normal scaphoid; however, later stages can show bone collapse, sclerosis, or cyst formation.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kienbock's disease is most directly related to the risk factors of avascular necrosis of the lunate and is characterized by specific radiographic changes.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with Cushing's syndrome is being evaluated for a drug that can reduce the synthesis of cortisol. Which of the following medications works by inhibiting the synthesis of glucocorticoids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Metyrapone

 

  • Metyrapone inhibits the enzyme 11β-hydroxylase, which is essential for the final step in cortisol synthesis in the adrenal cortex.
  •  By blocking this enzyme, metyrapone decreases the production of cortisol, making it useful in the diagnosis and management of Cushing's syndrome.
  • It is particularly used in testing the integrity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal (HPA) axis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mifepristone: Mifepristone is an anti-progestogen and also acts as a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist but does not inhibit the synthesis of glucocorticoids.

 

Option B. Flutamide: Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used primarily in the treatment of prostate cancer. It does not affect glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Option C. Finasteride: Finasteride is a 5-α reductase inhibitor used in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and androgenic alopecia. It inhibits the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT) and has no effect on glucocorticoid synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mifepristone is an Anti-Progestogen.
  • Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist.
  • Finasteride is a 5-α Reductase inhibitor.
  • Metyrapone is enzyme 11ß-hydroxylase inhibitor.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man presents with a persistent fear of social situations and avoids public speaking. His psychiatrist diagnoses social anxiety disorder. Which of the following statements about social anxiety disorder are true?

 

  1. It is more common in males than females.
  2. Cognitive-behavioral therapy is an effective treatment.
  3. Beta-blockers can be used for symptom management.
  4. Onset is typically in late adulthood.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

  • Statement 2: Cognitive-behavioral therapy is an effective treatment.
    • True. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) is considered a first-line treatment for social anxiety disorder. It helps individuals challenge and change their negative thoughts and behaviors related to social situations.
       
  • Statement 3: Beta-blockers can be used for symptom management.
    • True. Beta-blockers, such as propranolol, are sometimes used to manage physical symptoms of anxiety (like tremors and tachycardia) in performance or specific social situations, such as public speaking.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement 1: It is more common in males than females.
    • False. Social anxiety disorder is actually more common in females than in males. However, males may be more likely to seek treatment.
       
  • Statement 4: Onset is typically in late adulthood.
    • False. Social anxiety disorder usually has an onset in adolescence or early adulthood, not late adulthood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Social anxiety disorder is often treated effectively with CBT and beta-blockers can be used for performance-related anxiety, but it is more common in females and typically begins in adolescence.

questions.text: A healthcare facility is performing routine sterilization and disinfection of medical equipment to ensure complete removal of all microbial life, including bacterial spores. Which of the following disinfectants is not considered a sporicidal agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benzalkonium chloride

 

  • Benzalkonium chloride is a quaternary ammonium compound (QAC) that is commonly used as a surface disinfectant.
  • It is effective against a wide range of microbes including bacteria, fungi, and some viruses. However, it is not sporicidal and does not effectively destroy bacterial spores, which are highly resistant forms of microbial life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glutaraldehyde: This is a high-level disinfectant that is sporicidal and used for cold sterilization of heat-sensitive medical equipment.

 

Option B. Ethylene oxide: This is a gaseous sterilant that can be used for low-temperature sterilization and is effective against spores, although it requires prolonged exposure.

 

Option C. Formaldehyde: Formaldehyde is a sporicidal agent that is used for sterilizing instruments and disinfecting environments, particularly in vapor form.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with a head injury following a fall. On examination, he is found to have elevated blood pressure, a heart rate of 45 beats per minute, and irregular breathing patterns. Which of the following reflexes is most likely responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cushing's reflex

 

  • Cushing's reflex is a physiological response to increased intracranial pressure (ICP).
  •  It is characterized by the classic triad of hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.
