Option C. Vertebral artery: Incorrect. Injury to the vertebral artery typically results in posterior circulation strokes or dissections, rather than a subdural hematoma. This presentation is inconsistent with the bleeding pattern described.

 

Option D. Lenticulostriate artery: Incorrect. The lenticulostriate arteries are small perforating branches of the middle cerebral artery and are usually involved in deep intracerebral hemorrhages, particularly in patients with chronic hypertension. These do not cause the crescent-shaped hemorrhage seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Subdural hematomas occur due to the rupture of bridging veins, leading to a crescent-shaped hemorrhage that can cross suture lines but not the midline.
  • This condition is more common in elderly patients following trauma or falls due to increased susceptibility of the veins.

choices.text: PTH falls >20% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >50% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >10% within 10 minutes of removal of gland
PTH falls >30% within 10 minutes of removal of gland

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of primary hyperparathyroidism is scheduled for a focused parathyroidectomy due to a solitary parathyroid adenoma. During the procedure, intraoperative parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are monitored. Ten minutes after removing the parathyroid gland, his PTH level drops significantly. Which of the following changes in PTH levels would indicate that the resection was adequate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) PTH falls >50% within 10 minutes of removal of gland

 

  • To confirm that an adequate parathyroid gland has been removed during surgery for primary hyperparathyroidism, the parathyroid hormone (PTH) level should decrease by more than 50% within 10 minutes after the removal of the gland.
  • This method is based on the Miami criteria, which utilizes the short half-life of PTH (3-5 minutes).
  • A drop in PTH levels of more than 50% indicates that the hyperfunctioning parathyroid tissue has been successfully excised, and no other hyperactive parathyroid gland remains.
  • This rapid assay helps guide surgeons in real-time during the procedure, ensuring that further exploration is unnecessary if the criterion is met.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In primary hyperparathyroidism, a >50% drop in PTH levels within 10 minutes following the removal of the hyperfunctioning gland is used to confirm adequate resection during parathyroidectomy, according to the Miami criteria.

questions.text: 32-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty relaxing his grip after shaking hands. He also reports experiencing daytime sleepiness and episodes of palpitations. On examination, he has facial muscle wasting, a frontal balding pattern, and a delayed relaxation of the hand grip. His mother had similar symptoms. Genetic testing is performed and confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following trinucleotide repeats is most likely responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CTG

 

  • The patient's symptoms, including progressive muscle weakness, myotonia (difficulty relaxing muscles), facial muscle wasting, and a family history, are consistent with myotonic dystrophy.
  • Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is caused by an expansion of the CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19.
  • This trinucleotide repeat expansion leads to the abnormal expression of RNA-binding proteins, affecting multiple body systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CAG: CAG trinucleotide repeats are associated with Huntington's disease and some spinocerebellar ataxias, not myotonic dystrophy.

 

Option B. CGG: CGG repeat expansion is linked to fragile X syndrome, which presents with intellectual disability, not myotonia or muscle wasting.

 

Option D. GAA: GAA repeats are found in Friedreich's ataxia, a condition characterized by progressive neurological deterioration, not myotonic dystrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) is caused by an expansion of the CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene, leading to progressive muscle weakness, myotonia, and multi-systemic involvement.

choices.text: Increased mean arterial blood pressure (MAP)

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus is admitted to the ICU with septic shock. He is started on a norepinephrine infusion to maintain perfusion pressure. During therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate parameter to monitor to assess the effectiveness of norepinephrine therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Increased mean arterial blood pressure (MAP)

 

  • Norepinephrine is a first-line vasopressor used in the management of septic shock.
  •  It acts by stimulating α1 and α2 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance (SVR).
  •  It also stimulates β1 receptors, increasing cardiac contractility, which helps maintain cardiac output.
  • The primary goal of norepinephrine therapy in septic shock is to increase mean arterial pressure (MAP) to improve organ perfusion.
  •  Monitoring MAP is crucial, as it provides a direct measure of the pressure required to ensure adequate blood flow to the vital organs.
  •  A target MAP of ≥65 mm Hg is typically aimed for in septic shock management, indicating that the therapy is effective in maintaining sufficient perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradycardia: Norepinephrine may cause reflex bradycardia due to increased blood pressure, but monitoring heart rate alone does not directly assess the effectiveness of perfusion or organ function in this context.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: While heart rate is an important vital sign, it is not the primary indicator of the effectiveness of norepinephrine in improving perfusion. Tachycardia could indicate stress or poor perfusion but is not a direct measure of the success of vasopressor therapy.

 

Option C. Increased urine output: While increased urine output is a sign of improved kidney perfusion; it is not as direct or reliable a parameter as MAP for monitoring the overall effectiveness of norepinephrine in managing septic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Norepinephrine is a key vasopressor in the treatment of septic shock, used to increase mean arterial pressure (MAP) and improve organ perfusion.
  • MAP is the most reliable parameter for monitoring the effectiveness of norepinephrine therapy in septic shock, with a target of ≥65 mm Hg to ensure adequate perfusion.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old male who underwent a kidney transplant six months ago is being treated with cyclosporine to prevent graft rejection. Which of the following are known complications of cyclosporine therapy?

 

  1. Hypertension
  2. Pulmonary fibrosis
  3. Hirsutism
  4. Nephrotoxicity
  5. Hyperkalemia
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1,3,4,5

 

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressant used to prevent transplant rejection.
  •  Its most common adverse effects include:

 

1. Hypertension: Cyclosporine causes vasoconstriction, leading to elevated blood pressure.

 

3. Hirsutism: Unwanted facial and body hair growth is a frequent cosmetic side effect.

 

4. Nephrotoxicity: Cyclosporine can cause renal vasoconstriction, leading to a reduction in glomerular filtration rate and kidney damage.

 

5. Hyperkalemia: Cyclosporine can impair renal potassium excretion, resulting in elevated potassium levels.

 

Other Option:

 

  • 2. Pulmonary fibrosis: Pulmonary fibrosis is not associated with cyclosporine but may be seen with other immunosuppressive agents, like methotrexate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Common side effects of cyclosporine include hypertension, nephrotoxicity, hirsutism, and hyperkalemia.
  • Pulmonary fibrosis is not a known side effect of cyclosporine.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with pain and swelling in the upper part of his right leg. Imaging reveals a periosteal reaction in the diaphysis of the proximal tibia. A biopsy of the lesion is performed, and the histopathological image is shown below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for Synaptophysin and MIC-2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ewing sarcoma

 

  • The histological image provided shows characteristic features like small, round, blue cells, which are tightly packed with scant cytoplasm pattern and hyperchromatic Nuclei is suggestive of Ewing sarcoma.
  • Ewing sarcoma is a malignant small round blue cell tumor that typically affects the diaphysis of long bones, such as the tibia, in adolescents.
  • Clinical presentation often includes localized pain and swelling, along with a characteristic "onion-skin" periosteal reaction on X-ray imaging.
  • The diagnosis is supported by immunohistochemistry, which shows positivity for MIC-2 (CD99) and sometimes Synaptophysin, differentiating it from other small round cell tumors.
  • This makes Ewing sarcoma the most likely diagnosis in this case.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma: Chondrosarcoma is more common in older adults and typically affects the metaphysis or diaphysis of long bones but rarely presents in adolescents. It is characterized by cartilage matrix production rather than small round blue cells. Immunohistochemistry for MIC-2 would not be positive in chondrosarcoma.

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma (Giant cell tumor of bone): This condition typically occurs in the epiphysis of long bones in young adults. It presents as a lytic lesion and is histologically characterized by multinucleated giant cells. The immunohistochemical profile differs from that of Ewing sarcoma, as it does not show MIC-2 positivity.

 

Option D. Langerhans cell histiocytosis: Langerhans cell histiocytosis can involve bone lesions, often seen in children, but it is associated with eosinophilic granuloma and Langerhans cells with coffee bean-shaped nuclei. Immunohistochemistry would show positivity for CD1a and S-100, not MIC-2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ewing sarcoma is a small round blue cell tumor that commonly affects the diaphysis of long bones in adolescents.
  • It is characterized by immunohistochemical positivity for MIC-2 (CD99) and may show Synaptophysin positivity, distinguishing it from other bone tumors.

choices.text: To increase glucose absorption through sodium-glucose cotransport
To replenish lost potassium and sodium
To provide direct hydration to intestinal cells

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 2-day history of profuse watery diarrhea and signs of dehydration after a suspected case of cholera. The physician prescribes oral rehydration solution (ORS) that contains sodium chloride, potassium chloride, glucose, and sodium citrate. Which of the following is the primary purpose of sodium citrate in this ORS formulation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To correct metabolic acidosis

 

  • Sodium citrate in ORS serves as a base that helps correct metabolic acidosis, which commonly occurs in patients with severe diarrhea due to the loss of bicarbonate in the stools.
  • The citrate is metabolized in the liver into bicarbonate, helping to buffer the acid in the blood.
  • This is especially important in conditions like cholera, where severe acidosis can develop due to the large losses of alkaline fluid in the form of diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To increase glucose absorption through sodium-glucose cotransport: Incorrect. While ORS does facilitate glucose absorption via the sodium-glucose cotransport mechanism, this function is primarily driven by glucose and sodium, not sodium citrate.

 

Option B. To replenish lost potassium and sodium: Incorrect. Potassium chloride and sodium chloride in the ORS are responsible for replenishing lost electrolytes. Sodium citrate’s role is focused on correcting acidosis rather than directly replacing electrolytes.

 

Option D. To provide direct hydration to intestinal cells: Incorrect. Sodium citrate indirectly aids hydration by improving the intestinal absorption of sodium and water, but its main function is to help correct acidosis through its conversion to bicarbonate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sodium citrate in ORS is primarily used to correct metabolic acidosis resulting from the loss of bicarbonate during diarrhea.
  • It is converted to bicarbonate in the liver, helping to buffer acids in the blood and maintain pH balance.

questions.text:
Match the options:

 

  1. MC neoplasm of salivary gland
  2. MC malignant tumor of salivary gland
  3. Tumor of salivary gland with perineural invasion
  4. Tumor that shows hot spot in Tc-99 scan

 

 

  1. Warthin’s tumor
  2. Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  3. Pleomorphic adenoma
  4. Adenoid cystic carcinoma
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-d, 4-a

questions.text: A 38-year-old man from southern India presents with fever, headache, muscle weakness, and altered sensorium. He reports mosquito bites during his recent outdoor activities. Laboratory evaluation is initiated, and it is determined that a specific viral agent is the likely cause. Reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) is used as part of the diagnostic workup. Which of the following viruses is endemic to India and can be detected using this method?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) West Nile virus

 

  • West Nile Virus (WNV) is a member of the flavivirus genus and belongs to the Japanese encephalitis antigenic complex of the family Flaviviridae.
  • It is an arbovirus, meaning it is transmitted by arthropods, specifically mosquitoes.
  • The virus is endemic to many regions, including India, where antibodies against WNV were first detected in Mumbai in 1952.
  • Since then, WNV activity has been reported in southern, central, and western India.
  • WNV primarily involves a transmission cycle between birds and mosquitoes; however, humans and other mammals (e.g., horses) can also become infected.
  • The virus can cause neurological disease in some individuals, ranging from mild febrile illness to severe encephalitis or meningitis.
  • Diagnosis can be made by several methods, including RT-PCR, which helps detect viral RNA in blood or cerebrospinal fluid, especially during the acute phase of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hendra virus: Hendra virus is an emerging zoonotic virus found primarily in Australia. It is not endemic to India, and its primary reservoir is the flying fox (fruit bat).
 

Option C. Ebola virus: Ebola virus is primarily found in Africa and is not endemic to India. It can cause hemorrhagic fever and has a high mortality rate.
 

Option D. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is a flavivirus that primarily affects regions of Africa and South America. It is not endemic to India, and vaccination is used for prevention in endemic regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • West Nile Virus (WNV) is endemic to many parts of India and can cause neurological disease in humans.
  • It is transmitted by mosquitoes in a cycle involving birds as the reservoir.
  • RT-PCR can be used to diagnose WNV infection by detecting viral RNA during the acute phase.

questions.text:
A pediatric resident is reviewing neonatal reflexes with a medical student. They observe four different infants demonstrating various reflexes as shown in images labelled A, B, C, and D. The resident asks the student to match the reflexes to the images shown. Which of the following is the correct match of the neonatal reflexes to their corresponding images?

 

 

  1. Asymmetrical tonic neck reflex
  2. Palmar Grasp Reflex
  3. Parachute reflex
  4. Moro’s Reflex
questions.solution: Ans. D) A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

choices.text: NST and amniotic fluid index (AFI)
NST and gross fetal movements

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman at 38 weeks of gestation is undergoing an evaluation of fetal well-being due to concerns about decreased fetal movements. The obstetrician decides to perform a modified biophysical profile. Which of the following components is included in a modified biophysical profile?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NST and amniotic fluid index (AFI)

 

  • The correct answer is NST and amniotic fluid index (AFI).
  • A modified biophysical profile (BPP) is a simplified version of the full BPP, which includes non-stress test (NST) and amniotic fluid index (AFI).
  • The NST assesses fetal heart rate reactivity, while AFI provides an evaluation of the amniotic fluid volume, which is an indicator of chronic fetal well-being and placental function.
  • This combination gives a quick and effective assessment of fetal health.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NST and breathing movements: This option is incorrect because fetal breathing movements are a component of the full biophysical profile, not the modified version. The modified BPP focuses specifically on NST and AFI.

 

Option C. NST and fetal tone: This is incorrect as fetal tone is part of the full BPP rather than the modified BPP. In the modified version, the emphasis is placed on assessing acute (NST) and chronic (AFI) markers of fetal health.

 

Option D. NST and gross fetal movements: This is incorrect because gross fetal movements are also assessed in the full BPP. The modified BPP does not evaluate gross fetal movements but focuses on NST and AFI for a quicker assessment of fetal well-being.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The modified biophysical profile (BPP) includes non-stress test (NST) and amniotic fluid index (AFI), providing a rapid assessment of fetal well-being by evaluating both acute and chronic markers of fetal health.
  • This version is often used when a quick but effective evaluation of fetal status is required.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the relationship between a new medication and the risk of developing a rare adverse cardiac event in a cohort of 10,000 patients. Initial data on exposure is collected. After 5 years of follow-up, 100 patients develop the cardiac event (cases). For each of these patients, the researcher selects 200 patients from the same cohort who did not develop the event during the follow-up period (controls) to compare their exposure to the medication. What type of study design is being used in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nested case-control study

 

  • A nested case-control study is a type of case-control study that is conducted within a pre-existing cohort.
  • In this study design, cases (patients who develop the outcome of interest, such as a rare cardiac event) are identified from the cohort, and a set of controls is selected from those who do not develop the outcome during the follow-up period.
  • The exposures of cases and controls are then compared to assess associations.
  • This approach combines the prospective data collection of a cohort study with the efficiency of a case-control study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cross-sectional study: Incorrect. A cross-sectional study assesses prevalence by looking at exposure and outcome at a single point in time, rather than following patients over time or selecting cases and controls.

 

Option B. Cohort study: Incorrect. A cohort study follows a group over time to observe the development of outcomes based on exposure status. While the nested case-control study uses a cohort, it specifically selects cases and controls for a more focused analysis.

 

Option D. Case-control study: Incorrect. A traditional case-control study selects cases and controls from the general population without necessarily having a pre-defined cohort, whereas a nested case-control study selects both from within an existing cohort.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A nested case-control study is conducted within a pre-existing cohort, allowing researchers to efficiently study rare outcomes by focusing on cases and a matched subset of controls, providing the advantages of both prospective and retrospective study designs.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man undergoing evaluation for renal function had a test substance administered to measure his renal clearance. Laboratory results show a urine concentration of the substance as 120 mg/mL, a plasma concentration of 40 mg/mL, and a urinary flow rate of 20 mL/min. What is the renal clearance of this substance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 60 mL/min

 

Renal clearance of a substance is calculated using the formula:

 

 

 

  • Urine concentration = 120 mg/mL
  • Plasma concentration = 40 mg/mL
  • Urinary flow rate = 20 mL/min

 

Substitute these values into the formula:

 

 

So, the renal clearance of the substance is 60 mL/min.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To determine renal clearance, use the formula

 

 

This formula helps assess kidney function by evaluating how effectively a substance is removed from the blood and excreted in the urine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a history of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma is undergoing chemotherapy. The oncologist discusses different classes of chemotherapeutic agents, including those that are effective irrespective of the cell cycle phase (proliferation-independent). Which of the following drugs is not considered a proliferation-independent chemotherapeutic agent?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vincristine

 

  • Vincristine is a vinca alkaloid that acts by binding to tubulin and inhibiting microtubule formation, effectively blocking cells in the M phase of the cell cycle.
  •  This means that its activity is dependent on the cells being in a specific phase of proliferation, making it proliferation-dependent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Carmustine: Carmustine is an alkylating agent that works by forming cross-links in DNA, preventing replication and transcription. It is effective against both dividing and non-dividing cells, making it a proliferation-independent agent.

 

Option C. Melphalan: Melphalan is another alkylating agent that is effective in damaging DNA, regardless of the cell cycle phase, thus it is considered proliferation-independent.

 

Option D. Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is also an alkylating agent, working by cross-linking DNA strands, and can kill cells in both dividing and resting phases, making it proliferation-independent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vinca alkaloids like vincristine are proliferation-dependent agents, targeting cells in the M phase of the cell cycle.
  • Alkylating agents like carmustine, melphalan, and cyclophosphamide are proliferation-independent and can act on both dividing and non-dividing cells.

questions.text: A patient presents with episodes of jaundice and anemia. Laboratory testing reveals increased reticulocyte count and elevated indirect bilirubin levels. A test is performed that shows increased red blood cell lysis when exposed to hypotonic solutions. Which of the following conditions is most likely associated with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hereditary spherocytosis

 

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is characterized by a defect in the red blood cell membrane proteins (such as spectrin and ankyrin), leading to spherocytes that are more prone to hemolysis in hypotonic solutions.
  • The osmotic fragility test measures the extent of red blood cell lysis when placed in varying concentrations of hypotonic saline.
  • In hereditary spherocytosis, the increased fragility of red cells due to their shape results in increased hemolysis during the test, confirming the diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sickle cell anemia: This condition is due to a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to the formation of sickle-shaped cells. These cells have altered deformability but do not show increased osmotic fragility as seen in hereditary spherocytosis. The diagnosis is typically made by hemoglobin electrophoresis.

 

Option C. Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency: This condition leads to hemolysis triggered by oxidative stress. The osmotic fragility test is not used for diagnosis; instead, a G6PD enzyme assay is the diagnostic test.

 

Option D. Thalassemia: This is a genetic disorder affecting hemoglobin synthesis, leading to microcytic anemia. Osmotic fragility is not the primary diagnostic test; hemoglobin electrophoresis is used for diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by mutations in proteins like spectrin, ankyrin, band 3, or protein 4.2 that maintain the RBC cytoskeleton
  • This causes spherically shaped RBCs that are less deformable and more prone to lysis, especially in hypotonic environments
  • The osmotic fragility test is positive due to increased susceptibility to hemolysis in hypotonic saline
  • The diagnosis is confirmed with help of EMA flowcytometry.

choices.text: Central sensitization of pain pathways
Immune complex deposition in medium-sized arteries
Inflammatory disorder of the joints and periarticular structures

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 2-month history of bilateral shoulder and hip stiffness accompanied by pain that is most pronounced in the morning. She finds it increasingly difficult to perform daily activities, such as combing her hair and getting dressed. On physical examination, there is limited active range of motion in her shoulders and hips due to pain, but muscle strength testing reveals no true muscle weakness. Her laboratory tests show a markedly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), while X-rays of the affected joints appear normal. Which pathophysiological process best explains this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Inflammatory disorder of the joints and periarticular structures

 

  • The patient's presentation, characterized by bilateral shoulder and hip stiffness that is worse in the morning, limited movement due to pain, and an elevated ESR, is highly suggestive of polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR).
  • PMR is an inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the joints and periarticular structures, such as bursae and tendons, leading to pain and stiffness, particularly in the shoulders and hips.
  • The absence of muscle weakness and the normal joint X-rays further support this diagnosis, distinguishing PMR from other inflammatory and musculoskeletal conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inflammatory myopathy with skin involvement: This describes dermatomyositis, which presents with muscle weakness and characteristic skin changes such as a heliotrope rash. The absence of muscle weakness and normal X-ray findings make dermatomyositis unlikely in this case.

 

Option B. Central sensitization of pain pathways: This mechanism is seen in fibromyalgia, which involves widespread musculoskeletal pain, fatigue, and tender points without objective inflammatory markers like an elevated ESR. Fibromyalgia typically does not present with significant morning stiffness localized to the shoulders and hips.

 

Option C. Immune complex deposition in medium-sized arteries: This describes polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), a vasculitis that affects medium-sized arteries and leads to systemic symptoms, including organ dysfunction. It does not present with the classic stiffness and pain in the shoulder and hip girdles seen in PMR.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by proximal muscle stiffness and pain, particularly in the shoulders and hips, without true muscle weakness.
  • It is associated with elevated inflammatory markers such as ESR, and the symptoms typically respond well to low-dose corticosteroids

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of progressive fatigue, generalized weakness, a sensation of heaviness in the head, difficulty smiling, and a drooping left eyelid. Neurological examination reveals ptosis that significantly improves following the administration of edrophonium. Additional workup shows no cranial nerve deficits, and his reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type II hypersensitivity

 

  • The patient's symptoms and the improvement in ptosis with the administration of edrophonium strongly suggest myasthenia gravis (MG). MG is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the production of autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the neuromuscular junction.
  • These antibodies block, alter, or destroy the receptors, leading to muscle weakness and fatigue.
  • This autoimmune process is an example of a Type II hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies are directed against cell surface antigens, leading to tissue-specific effects.
  • The use of edrophonium, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, temporarily increases the availability of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, resulting in an improvement in muscle strength, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clonal anergy: Clonal anergy refers to the inactivation of specific immune cells, usually T or B cells, preventing them from responding to antigens. This mechanism is associated with immune tolerance rather than the production of pathogenic autoantibodies seen in myasthenia gravis.

 

Option B. Serum sickness: Serum sickness is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction involving the formation of immune complexes, typically after exposure to foreign proteins or medications. It presents with systemic symptoms such as fever, rash, and joint pain, not focal neuromuscular weakness.

 

Option C. SOD1 mutation: Mutations in the superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) gene are associated with familial amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive motor neuron loss. ALS does not exhibit improvement with edrophonium and does not primarily involve autoantibodies against the neuromuscular junction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder mediated by a Type II hypersensitivity reaction, where autoantibodies target acetylcholine receptors, resulting in muscle weakness that can temporarily improve with acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like edrophonium.

choices.text: It is combination of cholinergic and anticholinergic drug
This combination is approved for treatment of schizophrenia
It can cause urinary retention as an adverse effect

questions.text: A new combination therapy of xanomeline and trospium has recently been approved for the treatment of a psychiatric disorder. Which of the following statements about this combination is false?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is an irrational combination

 

  • This statement is false.
  • The combination of xanomeline (a muscarinic agonist) and trospium (a muscarinic antagonist) is rational because it is designed to leverage the central beneficial effects of enhancing muscarinic activity in the brain (with xanomeline) while mitigating the peripheral muscarinic side effects (using trospium).
  • This strategic use of an anticholinergic to manage side effects while promoting the therapeutic effect of a cholinergic drug represents a thoughtful and effective approach to pharmacotherapy in schizophrenia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a combination of cholinergic and anticholinergic drug: This statement is true. Xanomeline is a muscarinic cholinergic receptor agonist, and trospium is an anticholinergic drug. The rationale for this combination is that xanomeline targets muscarinic receptors to improve symptoms of schizophrenia, while trospium counteracts the peripheral cholinergic side effects of xanomeline, such as salivation and gastrointestinal distress.

 

Option B. This combination is approved for treatment of schizophrenia: This statement is true. The combination of xanomeline and trospium is designed to reduce the cognitive and behavioral symptoms of schizophrenia by enhancing cholinergic transmission in the brain while mitigating peripheral side effects through the anticholinergic action of trospium.

 

Option C. It can cause urinary retention as an adverse effect: This statement is true. Trospium, as an anticholinergic agent, can lead to urinary retention among other potential anticholinergic effects like dry mouth and constipation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The combination of xanomeline and trospium is designed to optimize the benefits of muscarinic receptor stimulation while minimizing peripheral side effects, making it a rational choice for treating schizophrenia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with symptoms of chronic fatigue, pallor, and difficulty concentrating. Laboratory tests reveal microcytic anemia, and a bone marrow biopsy shows ringed sideroblasts. The patient is diagnosed with sideroblastic anemia. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

 

  • Sideroblastic anemia is a type of anemia where the bone marrow produces ringed sideroblasts rather than healthy red blood cells.
  • The most common cause of this condition is a deficiency in the enzyme ALA synthase, which requires vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) as a cofactor.
  • Supplementation with pyridoxine is particularly effective in cases of sideroblastic anemia that are due to congenital pyridoxine-responsive forms or acquired deficiencies caused by medications like isoniazid.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Vitamin B12 is used to treat megaloblastic anemia, not sideroblastic anemia. B12 deficiency results in macrocytic red blood cells, which is different from the microcytic nature of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3: Vitamin B3 (niacin) is involved in energy metabolism but does not have a direct role in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia. It is not involved in the heme synthesis pathway that is impaired in sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option D. Thiamine (Vitamin B1): Thiamine is used in conditions like beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. It does not play a direct role in heme synthesis, making it ineffective in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sideroblastic anemia, characterized by the presence of ringed sideroblasts in the bone marrow, can be treated effectively with pyridoxine (vitamin B6) due to its role as a cofactor in heme synthesis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of poorly controlled diabetes mellitus was treated with high-dose corticosteroids for an episode of exacerbated asthma 4 weeks ago. He now presents with complaints of nasal congestion, bloody nasal discharge, and facial pain for the past 3 weeks. On examination, there is evidence of black eschar on the nasal mucosa. A nasal biopsy was obtained, and the histopathological image is shown. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mucor

 

  • The histopathological image shows broad, non-septate hyphae with irregular, right-angle branching, which is indicative of an infection with Mucorales species (Mucormycosis).
  • Mucormycosis typically presents in immunocompromised individuals, such as those with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus or those on corticosteroids.
  • Patients often present with sinus involvement, nasal discharge, facial pain, and blackening of skin, which is characteristic of the tissue necrosis caused by vascular invasion by Mucor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aspergillus: This fungus forms septate hyphae with acute-angle branching (approximately 45°). It is commonly found in aspergillosis, particularly in patients with chronic lung disease or severe immunocompromise, but it does not produce the broad, non-septate hyphae seen here.
 

Option C. Candida: Candida is seen as budding yeast or pseudohyphae, typically in mucosal infections or systemic candidiasis, and does not show the broad hyphal features seen in this image.
 

Option D. Trichosporon: Trichosporon forms yeast-like cells and does not produce the broad, non-septate hyphae indicative of Mucor. It is seen in systemic infections in severely immunocompromised individuals.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Mucormycosis should be suspected in patients with diabetes mellitus or who are on corticosteroids presenting with sinus involvement, blackening of skin, and facial pain.
  • Histopathology showing broad, non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching is characteristic of Mucorales infection.
  • Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial due to its rapid, invasive nature.

choices.text: The fetus is in breech presentation
The fetus is in cephalic presentation
The fetus is in oblique lie
The fetus is in compound presentation

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks gestation is undergoing a routine check-up. On abdominal palpation, the provider identifies a hard, ballotable structure near the upper abdomen. Which of the following best describes the likely fetal position?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) The fetus is in breech presentation

 

  • A ballotable hard structure felt during a fundal grip is typically the fetal head.
  • If this hard structure is felt at the upper abdomen (fundus), it suggests that the head is positioned upwards while the buttocks or legs are downwards, indicating a breech presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The fetus is in cephalic presentation: In a cephalic presentation, the fetal head is expected to be positioned downwards, near the pelvis. During fundal grip, a soft structure, which is the fetal buttocks, would be felt at the fundus instead of a hard, ballotable structure.

 

Option C. The fetus is in oblique lie: An oblique lie occurs when the fetus is positioned diagonally between the head-down and head-up positions. It would not typically result in a ballotable hard structure being felt directly at the fundus, as this position involves a more diagonal orientation of the fetus.

 

Option D. The fetus is in compound presentation: A compound presentation involves a situation where an extremity (such as a hand) is presenting alongside the main presenting part (head or breech). It does not explain the presence of a ballotable hard structure at the fundus and would not typically align with the findings of this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In obstetric examinations, a ballotable hard structure felt at the upper abdomen (fundus) during fundal grip indicates that the fetal head is positioned upwards, suggesting a breech presentation.
  • This assessment aids in determining the fetal presentation during antenatal care.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the sleep clinic with complaints of feeling unrefreshed after sleep and experiencing frequent awakenings. A polysomnography study is ordered, and the results show prominent features of sleep spindles and K-complexes. These findings are characteristic of which stage of sleep?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage 2 Non-REM sleep

 

  • Sleep spindles and K-complexes are characteristic features seen during Stage 2 of Non-REM sleep.
  • Sleep spindles are bursts of rapid, rhythmic brain wave activity, while K-complexes are sharp, high-amplitude waves followed by slower waves.
  • These features help in transitioning into deeper stages of sleep and play a role in memory consolidation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. REM sleep: This is incorrect because REM sleep is characterized by rapid eye movements, low-amplitude mixed-frequency EEG activity, and muscle atonia, not by sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Option B. Stage 1 Non-REM sleep: This is incorrect because Stage 1 Non-REM sleep is characterized by theta wave activity and is a lighter sleep stage. It lacks the distinctive sleep spindles and K-complexes seen in Stage 2.

 

Option D. Stage 3 Non-REM sleep: This is incorrect because Stage 3 Non-REM sleep, also known as deep sleep or slow-wave sleep, is marked by delta waves rather than sleep spindles and K-complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sleep spindles and K-complexes are key features of Stage 2 Non-REM sleep and play a role in sleep stability and memory consolidation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a nasal polypoid mass that has been slowly growing for several months. He works as a farmer and frequently bathes in stagnant water bodies. A biopsy of the mass is taken and reveals structures as shown in the image. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rhinosporidium seeberi

 

  • Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic pathogen known to cause rhinosporidiosis, which is characterized by polypoid masses in the nasal cavity and nasopharynx.
  • The image shows large sporangia filled with endospores, which are classic histopathological findings for Rhinosporidium seeberi.
  • Rhinosporidiosis is often acquired through exposure to stagnant water, and the organism cannot be cultured in standard laboratory media.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus species cause aspergillosis, which can present with sinus involvement, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. However, the histopathology typically shows septate hyphae, which is not seen here.
 

Option B. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides causes coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), typically presenting with spherules containing endospores, but not in the form of polypoid nasal masses.
 

Option D. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces causes blastomycosis, often presenting with pulmonary and skin involvement. Histologically, it appears as broad-based budding yeast rather than large sporangia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Rhinosporidium seeberi is associated with rhinosporidiosis, characterized by polypoid masses primarily in the nasal cavity.
  • It is histologically recognized by the presence of large sporangia filled with endospores.
  • It is typically acquired through exposure to stagnant water, and the diagnosis is confirmed by biopsy, as it cannot be cultured on standard media.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with major depressive disorder is started on paroxetine. After 5 days, he develops confusion, myoclonus, and hyperhidrosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serotonin syndrome

 

  • Serotonin syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur when there is an excess of serotonin in the central nervous system, often due to the use of medications like SSRIs (e.g., paroxetine).
  • Symptoms include mental status changes (confusion), neuromuscular abnormalities (e.g., myoclonus), and autonomic hyperactivity (e.g., hyperhidrosis, increased heart rate).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome: This condition is associated with antipsychotic medications and presents with hyperthermia, "lead-pipe" rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic dysregulation. It does not typically present with myoclonus and is more often associated with dopamine blockade rather than serotonin excess.

 

Option C. Delirium: Delirium involves acute confusion and cognitive impairment but does not typically present with myoclonus or autonomic hyperactivity like hyperhidrosis. It is a broader term for a state of acute confusion that can be caused by many factors.

 

Option D. Anticholinergic toxicity: Anticholinergic toxicity presents with symptoms such as dry skin, dry mouth, urinary retention, and dilated pupils, as well as altered mental status. It does not typically cause myoclonus or hyperhidrosis but rather symptoms like "dry as a bone" and "blind as a bat."

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Serotonin syndrome presents with confusion, myoclonus, and autonomic symptoms like hyperhidrosis, often triggered by serotonergic medications such as SSRIs.

 

 

 

  • Management includes discontinuation of serotonergic agents (most crucial), supportive care, and cyproheptadine.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of multiple pregnancy losses occurring during the second trimester. After a detailed evaluation, the physician considers various potential causes for these recurrent mid-trimester losses. Which of the following is least likely to be a cause in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chromosomal anomalies in the fetus

 

  • Fetal chromosomal anomalies are more commonly associated with first-trimester pregnancy losses rather than mid-trimester losses.
  • While these anomalies can cause spontaneous abortions, they are typically a cause of early pregnancy failure rather than recurrent losses in the second trimester.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome: APLA syndrome is a known cause of recurrent pregnancy loss, including losses in the second trimester. It is associated with thrombosis and placental insufficiency, leading to pregnancy complications.

 

Option C. Uterine didelphys: A structural abnormality like uterine didelphys can lead to recurrent pregnancy loss, especially during the second trimester, due to inadequate space or support for the growing fetus.

 

Option D. Cervical insufficiency: Cervical insufficiency is a common cause of mid-trimester pregnancy loss. It involves a weakened cervix that opens prematurely, leading to the loss of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chromosomal anomalies are more commonly associated with early pregnancy losses rather than mid-trimester losses, making them less likely to be the cause of recurrent second-trimester losses in comparison to other conditions like APLA syndrome or uterine anomalies.

questions.text: A newly joined medical officer is attending an ethics seminar focused on the responsibilities of medical professionals in adhering to international guidelines and declarations. A discussion arises about the ethical obligations of doctors to refuse participation in acts of torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. The medical officer recalls a specific declaration that explicitly prohibits doctors from participating in torture. Which of the following declarations includes these guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Declaration of Tokyo

 

  • The Declaration of Tokyo, established by the World Medical Association in 1975, specifically addresses the role of physicians concerning torture and other cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment or punishment.
  • It explicitly states that doctors should not be involved in these practices and must not provide any assistance or knowledge to facilitate torture or other forms of ill treatment.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Declaration of Helsinki: This declaration focuses primarily on ethical principles for medical research involving human subjects, emphasizing the safety, well-being, and informed consent of participants.
 

Option C. Declaration of Oslo: This declaration is less commonly referenced and primarily focuses on therapeutic abortion and other health care ethics, not specifically on torture.
 

Option D. Declaration of Geneva: While this declaration includes a pledge for doctors to maintain the utmost respect for human life, it is more of a modern-day Hippocratic Oath and does not specifically address participation in torture.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Declaration of Tokyo is a pivotal document that outlines the ethical duty of physicians to abstain from participating in, or facilitating, torture and other inhumane treatments.
  • It is essential for medical professionals to be aware of such guidelines to uphold the integrity and ethical standards of the medical profession, especially in settings where human rights are at risk.

questions.text: Match the eczemas in column A with the characteristic features given in column B .
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-d, 4-b

 

  • 1. Hair Dye Dermatitis → c. Paraphenylenediamine (PPD): Hair dye dermatitis is commonly caused by Paraphenylenediamine (PPD), a chemical found in many hair dyes. PPD is a well-known allergen and can cause allergic contact dermatitis, leading to redness, itching, and swelling in areas exposed to the dye, especially around the scalp and neck.
  • 2. Atopic Dermatitis → a. Subcapsular Cataract: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition that often presents in early childhood. A significant feature of severe or long-standing atopic dermatitis is the increased risk of developing subcapsular cataracts in adulthood, particularly in patients who have been treated with long-term corticosteroids.
  • 3. Irritant Contact Dermatitis → d. Sensitization Phase Absent: Unlike allergic contact dermatitis, irritant contact dermatitis does not involve an immune-mediated sensitization phase. It results from direct damage to the skin by irritants such as chemicals, soaps, or detergents. The inflammation is localized to the site of contact with the irritant.
  • 4. Bindi Dermatitis → b. Patch Test: Bindi dermatitis occurs from prolonged exposure to adhesives or dyes in decorative bindis. A patch test is used to identify the specific allergen causing the contact dermatitis in such cases, helping to pinpoint sensitivities to substances present in the bindi.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Primary closure of the wound
Application of a skin graft
Immediate debridement and tissue reconstruction
Antibiotics and delayed wound closure

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. On examination, his right leg shows a large, avulsed area where the skin and subcutaneous tissue have been torn off, exposing muscle and tendons. There is extensive soft tissue damage with compromised blood supply to the avulsed tissue. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Immediate debridement and tissue reconstruction

 

  • A degloving injury is a traumatic injury in which the skin and subcutaneous tissue are separated from the underlying fascia, muscles, and tendons, often resulting in extensive soft tissue damage and compromised blood supply.
  • This type of injury is common in high-energy trauma, such as motorcycle accidents, and requires immediate debridement to remove non-viable tissue, reduce infection risk, and promote healing.
  • Once debridement is done, further steps like tissue reconstruction can be planned, which may involve flap reconstruction or skin grafting depending on the extent of the injury and tissue loss. Delaying treatment can lead to infection, necrosis, and a poor functional outcome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Primary closure of the wound: Primary closure is not appropriate for a degloving injury because the tissue is avulsed and often non-viable. Closing such a wound without debridement would trap necrotic tissue and increase the risk of infection.

 

Option B. Application of a skin graft: Skin grafts may be needed in the future, but grafting is not the initial step in the management of a degloving injury. First, debridement and assessment of tissue viability must occur.

 

Option D. Antibiotics and delayed wound closure: While antibiotics may be indicated to prevent infection, delayed wound closure alone is not sufficient. The priority in a degloving injury is to promptly debride non-viable tissue and plan for reconstruction, either with flaps or skin grafts, depending on the extent of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a degloving injury, immediate debridement of non-viable tissue is crucial to prevent infection and promote healing. Tissue reconstruction with flaps or skin grafts follows debridement, depending on the extent of the injury.

choices.text: Lateralization of vocal cord
Tensioning of vocal cord
Medialization of vocal cord
Relaxation of vocal cord

questions.text: A 52-year-old professional singer presents with a low-pitched voice and vocal fatigue. She is evaluated for a surgical intervention to improve her vocal quality. After consultation, a phonosurgical technique is recommended. According to Isshiki’s classification, which type of thyroplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tensioning of vocal cord

 

  • Tensioning of vocal cord (Type IV).
  • This involves increasing the tension of the vocal cords and is typically used to raise the pitch of the voice by elongating the cords.
  • It is the procedure needed in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateralization of vocal cord (Type II): This procedure involves moving the vocal cord laterally and is typically used to widen the airway in cases of bilateral vocal cord paralysis. It is not used for altering pitch or vocal fatigue.

 

Option C. Medialization of vocal cord (Type I): This procedure is used to bring the vocal cord medially to improve glottic closure in cases of unilateral vocal cord paralysis or weakness, not for relaxation or pitch adjustment.

 

Option D. Relaxation of vocal cord (Type III): Type III thyroplasty involves the relaxation or shortening of the vocal cord. It is used for patients who have a high-pitched voice and need their vocal cords shortened to lower the pitch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IV thyroplasty, as described by Isshiki, involves lengthening of the vocal cord and is used to modify the pitch and tone of the voice, particularly in patients with low-pitched voice.
  • Recognizing the indications for different types of thyroplasty is essential for appropriate surgical management of voice disorders.

choices.text: By promoting calcium absorption in the intestines
By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion
By enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient presents with symptoms of hyperparathyroidism. Laboratory analysis shows elevated levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH). The accompanying graph shows changes in plasma calcium and phosphate levels after administration of PTH. Which of the following mechanisms explains how PTH increases plasma calcium levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) By increasing both osteoclastic activity and reducing renal calcium excretion

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases blood calcium levels through two primary mechanisms:
    1. Increasing osteoclastic activity: PTH stimulates osteoclasts indirectly by acting on osteoblasts, which in turn produce signals that promote osteoclast activity. Osteoclasts break down bone, releasing calcium into the bloodstream.
    2. Decreasing renal calcium excretion: PTH acts on the kidneys to increase calcium reabsorption in the distal tubules, thus reducing the amount of calcium excreted in the urine.
  • Together, these actions lead to an increase in plasma calcium levels, as shown in the graph.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. By stimulating osteoblastic activity: Osteoblasts are involved in bone formation and would decrease plasma calcium by promoting its deposition into bone. PTH initially targets osteoblasts to indirectly stimulate osteoclasts, but its primary effect on blood calcium is through osteoclast-mediated bone resorption.

 

Option B. By promoting calcium absorption in the intestines: While PTH indirectly promotes intestinal calcium absorption through its role in stimulating vitamin D activation, this mechanism is not the primary way that PTH raises serum calcium acutely. Its more immediate effects are through bone resorption and renal calcium retention.

 

Option D. By enhancing phosphate absorption in the intestine: PTH actually decreases phosphate reabsorption in the kidneys, leading to increased phosphate excretion. This is the opposite of what would be expected if PTH enhanced phosphate absorption. Reducing serum phosphate indirectly helps increase calcium levels by reducing calcium-phosphate complex formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parathyroid hormone (PTH) increases serum calcium levels primarily by stimulating osteoclasts to resorb bone and reducing renal calcium excretion, leading to increased blood calcium levels.

questions.text: A clinical researcher is analyzing the survival outcomes of two different treatment groups using Kaplan-Meier survival curves. To determine if there is a significant difference between the survival distributions of the groups, which of the following statistical tests is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cox proportional hazards test

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards test (also known as the Cox regression model) is used for comparing Kaplan-Meier survival curves when analyzing time-to-event data, such as comparing survival between two or more groups.
  • This test assesses the effect of various covariates on the survival time and can account for censoring (patients lost to follow-up).
  • It is particularly useful when researchers need to adjust for other variables that could affect survival time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANOVA: Incorrect. ANOVA (Analysis of Variance) is used for comparing the means of more than two groups, typically for continuous outcomes. It is not suitable for comparing survival distributions or time-to-event data.

 

Option B. Bland-Altman analysis: Incorrect. Bland-Altman analysis is used to assess agreement between two different measurement methods for continuous data. It is not designed for survival analysis or comparing survival curves.

 

Option C. Chi-square test: Incorrect. While the Chi-square test can be used to compare categorical variables and frequencies, it is not specifically used to compare survival curves. For comparing Kaplan-Meier curves, tests like the log-rank test or Cox proportional hazards test are more appropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • To compare Kaplan-Meier survival curves, the Cox proportional hazards test is used when accounting for covariates and adjusting for potential confounders. The log-rank test can also be used when comparing unadjusted survival curves between groups.

choices.text: They are not considered core features of the disorder
They typically respond well to antipsychotic medication
They can include deficits in attention and working memory
They only develop in the late stages of the illness

questions.text: Which of the following statement about cognitive symptoms in schizophrenia is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) They can include deficits in attention and working memory

 

  • Cognitive symptoms in schizophrenia often include difficulties with
    • Attention
    • Working memory
    • Executive functioning.
  • These impairments are considered core features of schizophrenia and significantly impact daily functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. They are not considered core features of the disorder : False, Cognitive symptoms are indeed considered core features of schizophrenia. They can significantly impair a person’s ability to function and are present throughout the course of the illness.

 

Option B. They typically respond well to antipsychotic medication : False, Cognitive symptoms are generally less responsive to antipsychotic medication compared to positive symptoms like hallucinations and delusions. Cognitive remediation therapy is often used to target these symptoms.

 

Option D. They only develop in the late stages of the illness : False, Cognitive deficits in schizophrenia often appear early, even before the onset of overt psychotic symptoms, and may persist throughout the course of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cognitive symptoms in schizophrenia:

 

  • They may be subtle, particularly early in the disease, but are very impairing and account for much of the disability associated with this disorder.
  • They include impairments of:
    • Attention
    • Working memory
    • Executive functioning

 

Symptom Profile of Schizophrenia:

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with difficulty in moving her leg outward after slipping on a wet floor. Physical examination reveals tenderness over the lateral aspect of her upper thigh. Imaging indicates a possible injury to the structure attached to the marked area in the image. Which of the following actions is primarily affected due to injury to the muscle attached at the marked site?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Abduction

 

  • The marked area in the image is the greater trochanter of the femur, which serves as the attachment site for muscles such as the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus.
  • These muscles are critical for the abduction of the thigh at the hip joint. They help to move the leg laterally and stabilize the pelvis during activities like walking.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adduction: Incorrect. Adduction of the thigh involves muscles like the adductor longus, adductor magnus, and gracilis, which attach to the medial side of the thigh and not to the greater trochanter.

 

Option B. Flexion: Incorrect. Thigh flexion is primarily performed by muscles such as the iliopsoas and rectus femoris, not the gluteus medius or gluteus minimus.

 

Option D. Extension: Incorrect. Thigh extension involves muscles like the gluteus maximus and hamstrings, which are not attached to the greater trochanter.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscles, which attach to the greater trochanter of the femur, are responsible for abduction of the thigh.
  • These muscles also play a crucial role in stabilizing the pelvis during ambulation.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with secondary amenorrhea following a spontaneous abortion six months ago. Her current laboratory results show an FSH level of 6 mIU/mL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine synechiae

 

  • The patient's presentation of secondary amenorrhea after a spontaneous abortion is highly suggestive of Asherman syndrome, which is characterized by the formation of intrauterine adhesions (synechiae).
  • These adhesions are often a result of trauma to the uterine lining, typically after a procedure such as dilation and curettage (D&C) following a miscarriage.
  • The normal FSH level indicates that the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is functioning normally, making uterine factors like synechiae the likely cause of amenorrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian failure: Ovarian failure usually results in elevated FSH levels due to the loss of negative feedback from the ovaries to the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. The normal FSH level in this patient suggests that her ovaries are still functional, making ovarian failure less likely.

 

Option B. Endometrial scarring: While endometrial scarring is related to the underlying cause (Asherman syndrome), "uterine synechiae" is a more specific term for the intrauterine adhesions that result in this condition. Therefore, this option is not the best answer when compared to "uterine synechiae."

 

Option C. Pituitary adenoma: A pituitary adenoma, such as a prolactinoma, typically presents with elevated prolactin levels and possibly suppressed FSH levels. In this case, the FSH level is normal, making a pituitary cause less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asherman syndrome is a cause of secondary amenorrhea following uterine trauma, such as dilation and curettage (D&C).
  • It is characterized by intrauterine adhesions (synechiae) that prevent normal endometrial function.
  • Normal FSH levels in the presence of amenorrhea and a history of uterine trauma should prompt evaluation for this condition.

choices.text: Lytic bone lesion with well-defined margins
Cortical thickening with periosteal reaction
Onion skin appearance of the cortex

questions.text: Which of the following describes the typical radiological appearance of osteosarcoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cortical thickening with periosteal reaction

 

  • This option accurately describes the typical radiological appearance of osteosarcoma.
  • The tumour often causes thickening of the cortex and can elicit a periosteal reaction, leading to a layered or "sunburst" appearance due to new bone formation.
  • This is a hallmark finding in osteosarcoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lytic bone lesion with well-defined margins: This description is more characteristic of certain benign bone lesions or metastatic lesions. Osteosarcoma typically presents as a destructive lesion that can be lytic but often has poorly defined margins rather than well-defined ones.

 

Option C. Onion skin appearance of the cortex: This description is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction seen in certain conditions, such as Ewing’s sarcoma or some types of chronic osteomyelitis. It refers to concentric layers of new bone formation and is not characteristic of osteosarcoma.

 

Option D. Sclerotic bone lesion: Sclerotic lesions are typically seen in conditions such as osteoblastic metastases or certain benign lesions like osteomas. Osteosarcoma usually presents as a mixed pattern of lytic and sclerotic features, but it is more commonly known for its aggressive, lytic nature rather than being purely sclerotic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteosarcoma typically presents with cortical thickening and a periosteal reaction which reflects its aggressive nature and impact on the surrounding bone.

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with jejunoileal atresia and an abdominal X-ray reveals a triple bubble sign. Intra-operative findings are as shown. What type of jejunoileal atresia does this describe?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type 3b

 

  • Type 3b jejunoileal atresia is characterized by the "apple peel" or "Christmas tree" deformity, where there is a large mesenteric gap, and the remaining small intestine is twisted around a single blood vessel.
  • This condition results in a loss of a portion of the mesentery, causing the characteristic appearance on imaging.
  • The triple bubble sign is also seen in proximal jejunoileal atresia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1: This involves a mucosal web or diaphragm causing the atresia. It does not present with an apple peel deformity.

 

Option B. Type 2: In this type, the atretic ends of the bowel are connected by a fibrous cord with intact mesentery, but there is no mesenteric gap or apple peel deformity.

 

Option D. Type 4: This type involves multiple atresias, with the bowel appearing like a string of sausages, but it does not present with the apple peel deformity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type 3b jejunoileal atresia presents with an "apple peel" deformity and involves a large mesenteric gap, often requiring surgical intervention to address the anatomical abnormality.

choices.text: B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection
T-cell receptor gene rearrangement studies

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent bacterial infections, including pneumonia and otitis media. Laboratory evaluation reveals significantly reduced levels of all immunoglobulins (IgG, IgA, and IgM). Which of the following tests would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B cell tyrosine kinase activity detection

 

  • In this case, a 5-year-old boy with recurrent bacterial infections (e.g., pneumonia, otitis media) and low immunoglobulin levels (IgG, IgA, IgM) suggests X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton's disease).
  • This condition is due to mutations in the BTK gene, which is essential for B cell development.
  • The diagnosis is confirmed through B cell tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity detection, which directly identifies defects in BTK function.
  • This defect impairs B cell maturation, leading to a significant deficiency in immunoglobulins, making it the most definitive test for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum immunoglobulin electrophoresis: It measures levels of different immunoglobulins but cannot specifically identify a defect in BTK. While immunoglobulin levels would be low in this condition, this test alone is not confirmatory for Bruton's disease.

 

Option C. T-cell receptor gene rearrangement studies: These are used to evaluate T-cell abnormalities or clonality but do not provide information regarding B cell function or BTK mutations, making it irrelevant for diagnosing Bruton's disease.

 

Option D. Neutrophil oxidative burst assay: It assesses the function of neutrophils in conditions like chronic granulomatous disease (CGD). It does not help in diagnosing a B cell maturation defect such as Bruton's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In X-linked agammaglobulinemia (Bruton's disease), detection of B cell tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity is essential for confirming the diagnosis, as BTK mutations prevent B cell maturation and result in low immunoglobulin levels and recurrent bacterial infections.

questions.text: In patients with severe osteoarthritis, which of the following is considered a contraindication for arthroplasty?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Active infection

 

  • Active infection is indeed a contraindication for arthroplasty.
  • Performing surgery on a joint with an active infection can lead to further complications, including the spread of infection, poor healing, and implant failure.
  • It is crucial to treat any infections prior to considering joint replacement surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Obesity is not an absolute contraindication for arthroplasty but rather a relative contraindication. While obesity increases the risk of complications such as infection, wound healing issues, and implant failure, many surgeons will still proceed with the surgery if the benefits outweigh the risks. Weight loss prior to surgery may be encouraged to improve outcomes.

 

Option C. Previous knee surgery: Previous knee surgery is not necessarily a contraindication for arthroplasty. Many patients who have undergone prior surgeries, such as arthroscopy or ligament repair, can still be candidates for joint replacement. The decision depends on the condition of the joint and the specific surgical history. However, previous surgeries may complicate the procedure or affect the recovery process.

 

Option D. Moderate renal impairment: Moderate renal impairment is generally not an absolute contraindication for arthroplasty. While it may increase the risk of perioperative complications, many patients with moderate renal impairment can still safely undergo surgery with appropriate management and monitoring. The surgical team will typically assess the patient's overall health and kidney function prior to proceeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active infection is the primary contraindication due to the high risk of complications if surgery is performed in the presence of infection.

questions.text: Match the following reporting guidelines with their corresponding area of application:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-E, 2-A, 3-B, 4-C, 5-D

 

  1. AGREE (Appraisal of Guidelines for Research and Evaluation): E. This tool is used to assess the quality of clinical practice guidelines (CPGs). It helps to ensure that guidelines are rigorously developed, transparent, and applicable to clinical practice.
  2. COREQ (Consolidated Criteria for Reporting Qualitative Research): A. COREQ is a 32-item checklist designed specifically for reporting qualitative research, focusing on studies that use interviews and focus groups. It ensures that qualitative studies are reported with sufficient detail and rigor.
  3. ARRIVE (Animal Research Reporting of In Vivo Experiments): B. These guidelines provide a checklist for reporting animal research. The goal of the ARRIVE guidelines is to improve the transparency and reproducibility of studies involving animal experiments.
  4. SQUIRE (Standards for Quality Improvement Reporting Excellence): C. SQUIRE guidelines provide a framework for reporting on quality improvement (QI) studies. They ensure that QI research is reported systematically, covering aspects like study design, context, and outcomes to improve healthcare delivery.
  5. CHEERS (Consolidated Health Economic Evaluation Reporting Standards): D. CHEERS is a guidance document that provides a checklist for reporting health economic evaluations. It aims to ensure that economic studies in healthcare are reported with a minimum level of quality, focusing on cost-effectiveness, cost-utility, and cost-benefit analyses.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is being considered for treatment with a drug that acts as a dual agonist of both PPAR alpha and PPAR delta receptors. Which of the following medications is follow this mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elafibranor

 

  • Elafibranor is a dual PPAR alpha and delta agonist.
  • It has been recently approved by FDA for treatment of primary biliary cholangitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pioglitazone:  Pioglitazone is a thiazolidinedione class of drug and primarily acts as a PPAR gamma agonist. It is commonly used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes for its insulin-sensitizing effects.

 

Option B. Telmisartan:  Telmisartan is an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) used primarily for the treatment of hypertension. It also has some PPAR gamma modulatory activity, but it is not a dual PPAR gamma and delta agonist.

 

Option C. Saroglitazar:  Saroglitazar is a medication mainly used to treat dyslipidemia in diabetic patients. It acts as a dual PPAR alpha/gamma agonist, but it does not have significant action on PPAR delta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Elafibranor acts as a dual agonist of PPAR alpha and PPAR delta receptors, making it suitable for conditions like non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) where modulation of lipid metabolism and inflammation is beneficial.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman, who is in her second trimester, presents with complaints of decreased fetal movement for the past few days. A fetal ultrasound reveals hydrops fetalis with evidence of fetal anemia. Laboratory investigations reveal a history of exposure to a daycare center, where there were cases of a viral exanthem among children. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for the non-immune hydrops fetalis seen in this fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

 

  • Parvovirus B19 has a special affinity for erythroid progenitor cells found in adult bone marrow and the fetal liver.
  • When a pregnant woman is infected with Parvovirus B19, the virus can cross the placenta and infect the fetus.
  • This infection disrupts red blood cell production, leading to severe anemia in the fetus, which can result in non-immune hydrops fetalis.
  • Hydrops fetalis manifests as excessive fluid accumulation in fetal compartments, often leading to fetal demise.
  • The greatest risk to the fetus occurs during the second trimester, when rapid erythropoiesis is critical for fetal growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cytomegalovirus (CMV): CMV can cause congenital infection with neurological impairment and growth restriction but is not typically associated with non-immune hydrops fetalis due to severe anemia.
 

Option B. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV): EBV primarily causes infectious mononucleosis and is not a common cause of congenital infection or hydrops fetalis.
 

Option D. Human Papillomavirus (HPV): HPV is known to cause genital warts and cervical dysplasia, but it is not associated with fetal infections or hydrops fetalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Parvovirus B19 can cross the placenta and infect the fetus, leading to non-immune hydrops fetalis due to severe fetal anemia.
  • The virus has a particular tropism for erythroid progenitor cells and poses the greatest risk during the second trimester of pregnancy, making early diagnosis and monitoring essential for at-risk pregnancies.

choices.text: Both FSH and LH decreased
Both FSH and LH elevated

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with irregular menstrual cycles and signs of hirsutism, including excessive facial hair growth. An ultrasound reveals enlarged ovaries with multiple small cysts. Which of the following hormonal findings is most consistent with her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LH > FSH

 

  • The characteristic hormonal finding in Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is increased LH to FSH ratio, often seen as LH > FSH.
  • In PCOS, the pulsatile release of GnRH is altered, leading to an increased secretion of luteinizing hormone (LH) relative to follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).
  • This hormonal imbalance contributes to anovulation and the clinical manifestations of PCOS, such as irregular menses and hyperandrogenism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FSH > LH: This is not consistent with PCOS. In PCOS, LH levels are typically elevated relative to FSH, not the other way around.

 

Option C. Both FSH and LH decreased: This finding is not characteristic of PCOS. Decreased levels of both hormones may be seen in hypogonadotropic hypogonadism but not in PCOS.

 

Option D. Both FSH and LH elevated: While LH levels can be elevated, FSH levels do not increase proportionally in PCOS. The ratio is skewed towards higher LH levels compared to FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS) is typically associated with an increased LH to FSH ratio, reflecting altered GnRH secretion patterns, which contribute to the clinical and endocrine features of the condition.

choices.text: Doppler ultrasound of the hepatic veins

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with right upper quadrant abdominal pain and shortness of breath. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. On examination, he has jaundice, a distended abdomen with a positive fluid wave, and tender hepatomegaly. A grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is auscultated along the right upper sternal border. Laboratory studies reveal a hemoglobin level of 19 g/dL, AST of 450 U/L, ALT of 350 U/L, and total bilirubin of 2.1 mg/dL. Abdominal ultrasound shows a congested liver with dilated hepatic veins. Given these findings, what is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Doppler ultrasound of the hepatic veins

 

  • This patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and lab results are consistent with hepatic vein obstruction, also known as Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • The presentation of right upper quadrant pain, tender hepatomegaly, jaundice, and ascites (distended abdomen) points toward liver congestion.
  • The elevated hemoglobin suggests polycythemia, which is associated with hypercoagulable states that can lead to hepatic vein thrombosis.
  • Doppler ultrasound of the hepatic veins is the most appropriate next step, as it can assess blood flow and identify any obstruction in the hepatic veins, confirming the diagnosis of Budd-Chiari syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatitis serologic panel: While viral hepatitis can cause liver enzyme elevations and jaundice, it typically does not present with ascites or tender hepatomegaly in the context of acute right upper quadrant pain. Additionally, a congested liver and polycythemia are not characteristic findings of a viral infection.

 

Option B. Serum ferritin and transferrin saturation: Increased iron absorption, as seen in hemochromatosis, can lead to liver dysfunction. However, hemochromatosis usually presents with chronic liver disease signs, such as cirrhosis, diabetes, and skin pigmentation ("bronze diabetes"). The acute presentation here, along with congested hepatic veins on imaging, is more consistent with hepatic vein obstruction.

 

Option D.
