Ans. C) Impaired generation of reduced glutathione

 

  • G6PD (glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase) deficiency is characterized by a decreased ability to generate NADPH, which is crucial for maintaining the levels of reduced glutathione (GSH) in red blood cells (RBCs).
  • Reduced glutathione plays a key role in detoxifying reactive oxygen species (ROS) and preventing oxidative damage to RBCs.
  • Without adequate levels of reduced glutathione, RBCs become more susceptible to oxidative stress, leading to hemolysis, especially after exposure to certain drugs, infections, or fava beans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reduced scavenging of RBCs by macrophages: In G6PD deficiency, there is an increased, not decreased, scavenging of damaged RBCs by macrophages. Oxidative damage leads to hemoglobin denaturation, forming Heinz bodies, which are then removed by splenic macrophages.

 

Option B. Decreased production of NADH in red blood cells: G6PD is involved in the pentose phosphate pathway and generates NADPH, not NADH. NADPH is essential for maintaining the oxidative balance in RBCs by regenerating reduced glutathione. Thus, this option is incorrect.

 

Option D. Decreased membrane lipid peroxidation: G6PD deficiency leads to increased membrane lipid peroxidation due to reduced levels of NADPH and glutathione. The resulting oxidative damage makes RBCs more fragile, leading to hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • G6PD deficiency impairs the production of NADPH, which in turn leads to reduced levels of glutathione, making red blood cells more vulnerable to oxidative damage.
  • This vulnerability can trigger hemolysis, particularly after exposure to oxidative stressors such as certain medications or infections.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with bipolar disorder presents to the clinic with complaints of increasing fatigue, confusion, and nausea over the past few weeks. He has been taking a mood-stabilizing medication for the last 5 months. On examination, mild jaundice is noted. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver transaminases and increased serum ammonia levels. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Valproate

 

  • Valproate is a commonly used anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer for conditions like bipolar disorder and seizure disorders.
  • One of its adverse effects is hepatotoxicity, which can present with elevated liver enzymes and jaundice.
  •  Valproate also disrupts the urea cycle, leading to hyperammonemia.
  • Hyperammonemia often results in symptoms like fatigue, altered mental status, and nausea.
  • The risk of these adverse effects is particularly significant in patients during the initial months of therapy or those on multiple antiepileptic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is also a mood stabilizer and anticonvulsant but is not typically associated with liver dysfunction or hyperammonemia. Its main side effects include rash and, in rare cases, Stevens-Johnson syndrome.

 

Option B. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine can cause liver enzyme elevation but is less commonly associated with significant liver dysfunction or hyperammonemia. Common adverse effects include hyponatremia, bone marrow suppression, and rash.

 

Option D. Topiramate: Topiramate is an anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer that can cause side effects such as weight loss, cognitive dysfunction, and nephrolithiasis. It is not commonly linked with liver dysfunction or hyperammonemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Valproate can cause hepatotoxicity and hyperammonemia, particularly during the early stages of treatment.
  • It is essential to monitor liver function tests and serum ammonia in patients taking valproate, especially if symptoms such as fatigue or jaundice develop.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, excessive sweating, unintentional weight loss, and occasional gingival bleeding. He has a past medical history of radiation therapy. On physical examination, there is notable splenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal: hemoglobin 9 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) 86 fL, white blood cell count (WBC) of 110,000/mm³ with a differential showing 24% segmented neutrophils, 1% blasts, 11% lymphocytes, and a platelet count of 650,000/mm³. Molecular testing identifies the presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Imatinib therapy

 

  • This patient’s presentation and laboratory findings are characteristic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), particularly the chronic phase.
  • The presence of leukocytosis with a marked increase in the WBC count, thrombocytosis, and splenomegaly, along with molecular confirmation of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, confirms the diagnosis.
  • The first-line treatment for CML is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI), such as imatinib, which specifically targets the BCR-ABL1 oncoprotein. Imatinib therapy effectively reduces disease progression, controls symptoms, and improves survival in patients with CML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vincristine, prednisone, and asparaginase therapy: This regimen is used in the treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), not CML. The patient's presentation, particularly the identification of the BCR-ABL1 gene, points towards CML rather than ALL.

 

Option B. Cytarabine and daunorubicin therapy: This is a standard induction chemotherapy regimen for acute myeloid leukemia (AML). However, the patient's low percentage of blasts (1%) and molecular findings are more consistent with CML in the chronic phase rather than AML.

 

Option C. Allogeneic stem cell transplantation: While allogeneic stem cell transplantation may be considered in advanced or refractory cases of CML or if the patient has failed TKI therapy, it is not the first-line treatment for CML in the chronic phase, particularly when TKIs like imatinib are available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene in a patient with leukocytosis, thrombocytosis, and splenomegaly is diagnostic of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).
  • Imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, is the first-line treatment that specifically targets the abnormal protein produced by the BCR-ABL1 fusion gene, providing effective disease control.

choices.text: 4 contractions in 20 minutes with cervical changes

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion for diagnosing preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cervix being posterior in position

 

  • Preterm labor is defined as labor occurring before 37 weeks of gestation.
  • Key diagnostic criteria for preterm labor include regular uterine contractions accompanied by cervical changes such as effacement (thinning) and dilation.
  • A posterior cervix is not a criterion for diagnosing preterm labor and does not contribute to the assessment of labor progression.
  • Cervical position is more relevant in assessing labor progress, but not in diagnosing preterm labor specifically.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: This is a significant finding that suggests cervical changes consistent with labor. Cervical dilation of more than 2 cm, especially in the presence of contractions, is a hallmark of preterm labor.

 

Option C. Cervical effacement > 80%: Cervical effacement (thinning of the cervix) is a key component in the diagnosis of labor. An effacement greater than 80% indicates that the cervix is significantly thinning, which, combined with contractions, supports a diagnosis of preterm labor.

 

Option D. 4 contractions in 20 minutes with cervical changes: Regular uterine contractions, especially when they are associated with cervical changes (dilation or effacement), are diagnostic of preterm labor. This frequency of contractions with cervical change is a recognized criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Preterm labor is diagnosed based on regular uterine contractions accompanied by cervical changes such as dilation or effacement occurring before 37 weeks gestation.
  • Cervical position (posterior or anterior) is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the hospital with high-grade fever, severe headache, and a maculopapular rash involving the trunk and extremities, including the palms and soles. He reports a recent history of outdoor activities, including hiking in a wooded area. Laboratory testing is initiated, including a Weil-Felix test. Which of the following is most likely to show positive results with both OX19 and OX2 antigens on the Weil-Felix test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Spotted fever

 

  • The Weil-Felix test is a serologic test that uses certain strains of Proteus bacteria (OX2, OX19, and OXK) as antigens to detect antibodies against rickettsial infections.
  • A positive reaction with both OX19 and OX2 antigens is indicative of the spotted fever group, such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever or Indian tick typhus.
  • The spotted fever group of rickettsiae, which includes Rickettsia rickettsii (causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever), cross-reacts with both OX19 and OX2 antigens on the Weil-Felix test, giving a positive result.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Scrub typhus: Scrub typhus is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and shows a positive reaction only with OXK antigen on the Weil-Felix test. It does not react with OX19 or OX2, distinguishing it from the spotted fever group.

 

Option C. Epidemic typhus: Epidemic typhus is caused by Rickettsia prowazekii and only gives a positive reaction with OX19 antigen. It does not show a positive result with OX2, unlike the spotted fever group.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weil-Felix Results:

 

  • Epidemic and endemic typhus: Positive with OX19 antibody (↑ OX 19 Ab)
  • Tickborne spotted fever: Positive with both OX19 and OX2 antibodies (↑ OX 19 and OX 2 Ab)
  • Scrub typhus: Positive with OXK antibody (↑ OX K Ab)
  • Negative in:
    • Rickettsial pox
    • Q fever
    • Ehrlichiosis
    • Bartonellosis

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl presents with heavy and irregular menstrual bleeding since menarche, which began a year ago. She reports periods lasting over 10 days with variable intervals between cycles. Physical examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anovulation

 

  • Puberty menorrhagia often occurs due to anovulation, especially in the first few years following menarche.
  • During this time, the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis is immature, leading to irregular cycles without ovulation.
  • Anovulation results in unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, which can lead to excessive and irregular shedding, causing heavy menstrual bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bleeding disorder: Although bleeding disorders, such as von Willebrand disease, can present with heavy menstrual bleeding, they are less common than anovulation in adolescents. Bleeding disorders should be considered if there is a history of prolonged bleeding, easy bruising, or a family history of bleeding disorders.

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis is less common in adolescents, especially as a cause of menorrhagia soon after menarche. It is typically associated with dysmenorrhea (painful periods) and chronic pelvic pain rather than isolated heavy menstrual bleeding.

 

Option D. Uterine malignancy: Uterine malignancy is extremely rare in adolescents and is not a typical cause of menorrhagia in this age group. Other causes, such as anovulation, are far more common and should be considered first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anovulation is the most common cause of puberty menorrhagia in adolescent girls, occurring due to the immaturity of the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with fever, joint pain, and a newly detected heart murmur. He had a sore throat about 3 weeks prior that went untreated, and a throat swab culture at that time showed presence of Streptococcus pyogenes. Which mechanism is most responsible for the development of his current condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cross-reactivity with bacterial antigens

 

  • Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) results from an autoimmune response triggered by a prior infection with Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus).
  • The immune system produces antibodies against streptococcal M proteins, which mistakenly cross-react with proteins in the heart, joints, and other tissues, causing inflammation.
  • This process is known as molecular mimicry and is the primary mechanism behind ARF.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct tissue invasion: ARF is not caused by the direct invasion of tissues by Streptococcus but rather by the immune system's response to the bacterial infection.

 

Option B. Release of inflammatory cytokines: While cytokines play a role in inflammation, they are not directly responsible for the autoimmune nature of ARF.

 

Option D. Toxin production by Streptococcus: Streptococcal toxins can cause conditions like scarlet fever but are not the cause of the autoimmune response seen in ARF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF) is an autoimmune reaction where antibodies against Streptococcus pyogenes cross-react with host tissues, leading to inflammation in organs such as the heart and joints.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with chronic pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and difficulty conceiving. Pelvic ultrasound is performed, and the image below is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometriosis

 

  • The ultrasound image provided shows a characteristic "ground-glass" appearance of an endometrioma, which is commonly associated with endometriosis.
  • Endometriosis is a condition where endometrial tissue is present outside the uterus, often causing symptoms such as dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and infertility. 
  • These findings, along with the patient's clinical history, make endometriosis the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubal blockage: Tubal blockages can contribute to infertility, but they are not typically associated with the characteristic ultrasound appearance seen here, nor do they cause the "ground-glass" appearance.

 

Option C. Adenomyosis: Adenomyosis involves the invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium of the uterus, leading to a "globular" uterine appearance on ultrasound. It does not present with an isolated cystic structure as seen in the image.

 

Option D. Ovarian cyst: While ovarian cysts can be seen on ultrasound, the specific appearance of a homogenous, ground-glass appearance points more towards an endometrioma rather than a simple cyst.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Endometriosis often presents with dysmenorrhea, chronic pelvic pain, and infertility. On ultrasound, endometriomas (associated with endometriosis) appear with a homogenous ground-glass echotexture.

questions.text: Calculate the Burn Surface Area (BSA) for a patient with a burn involving the chest abdomen, right upper limb, and right thigh up to knee (circumferential):
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 36% 

 

According to the ‘Rule of Nine’, BSA is calculated as:

  • Chest and Abdomen = 18%
  • Right Upper limb = 9%
  • Right Thigh = 9%

Total = 18% + 9% + 9% = 36%

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Rule of Nines is a method used to estimate the total body surface area affected by burns.
  • It divides the body into sections that represent approximately 9% of the total surface area, facilitating quick and effective assessment and treatment planning for burn patients.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is being ventilated in the ICU following severe head trauma. The anesthesiologist uses the breathing circuit as shown in the image below. It features an inner tube that delivers fresh gas to the patient and an outer tube for exhalation through an adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve. Which type of Mapleson circuit does this belong to?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mapleson D

 

  • The circuit shown in the image is the Bain's circuit, which is a coaxial modification of the Mapleson D circuit. It consists of two tubes: an inner inspiratory tube that delivers fresh gas to the patient, and an outer expiratory tube that allows exhaled gases to exit through an adjustable pressure limiting (APL) valve.
  • The coaxial design makes it efficient for maintaining warm and humidified air, which is especially useful in clinical settings where controlled ventilation is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mapleson A: This circuit is more efficient for spontaneous ventilation but not suitable for controlled ventilation as it requires higher fresh gas flow. It has a different design and tubing arrangement than the Bain’s circuit.

 

Option B. Mapleson B: This is an uncommon circuit, and it is less efficient in terms of fresh gas flow requirements compared to the Bain’s circuit.

 

Option C. Mapleson C: This circuit is typically used for short-term ventilation in the operating room. It lacks the coaxial arrangement seen in the Bain’s circuit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bain's circuit is a modified Mapleson D circuit, featuring a coaxial design that allows efficient ventilation with controlled fresh gas flow, making it suitable for both spontaneous and controlled ventilation scenarios.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with a history of recurrent fevers and a recent episode of severe pneumonia. Physical examination reveals mild pallor, oral thrush, micrognathia, low-set right ear, and areas of patchy hypopigmentation on the face, trunk, and extremities, along with silver-gray hair. The peripheral blood smear reveals abnormal inclusions as shown in the image. What is the underlying defect associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Defective phagolysosome fusion

 

  • The clinical presentation, including recurrent infections, hypopigmentation, and the presence of abnormal inclusions on the peripheral smear, is suggestive of Chediak-Higashi syndrome.
  • This rare genetic disorder is characterized by a defect in the LYST gene, leading to impaired phagolysosome fusion within phagocytes.
  • The inability of lysosomes to fuse properly results in the accumulation of large granules in neutrophils and other immune cells, leading to recurrent infections due to impaired microbial killing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased lysosomal trafficking: While defects in lysosomal trafficking could impair cell function, the increased lysosomal trafficking is not likely to cause the characteristic giant granules in neutrophils or the skin and hair abnormalities seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

 

Option C. Defective chemotaxis: Defective chemotaxis can lead to conditions like leukocyte adhesion deficiency, which results in severe bacterial infections but does not present with abnormal granules in neutrophils or the hypopigmentation seen in this case.

 

Option D. Defect in RAG gene: A defect in the RAG gene affects lymphocyte development, leading to conditions like SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency), which presents with recurrent infections but not with the specific abnormal granules or hypopigmentation seen in Chediak-Higashi syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chediak-Higashi syndrome is caused by defective phagolysosome fusion due to mutations in the LYST gene, leading to characteristic giant granules in neutrophils, hypopigmentation, and recurrent infections.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with chronic kidney disease is being treated with Drug Y, which is typically administered at a rate of 60 mg/hour. The drug is eliminated through the following pathways: 70% by renal excretion, 15% by hepatic metabolism, and 15% by biliary secretion. His current GFR is 45 mL/min (normal GFR is 90 mL/min), and his liver and biliary functions are normal. What should be the adjusted dose rate of Drug Y for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 39 mg/hour

 

  • In this scenario, 70% of Drug Y is eliminated through the renal route, and 30% is eliminated by non-renal routes (15% hepatic metabolism and 15% biliary secretion).
  • The patient's GFR is reduced to 45 mL/min, which is 50% of normal renal function (normal being 90 mL/min). This means that the renal clearance capacity is also reduced by 50%.

 

To calculate the new dose:

 

  • 30% of the drug is eliminated by non-renal routes, which remains unchanged.
  • 70% of the drug is eliminated renally, but due to the reduced GFR, this is adjusted to 50% of the renal capacity, resulting in 35% renal elimination.

 

Thus, the total effective elimination in this patient is:

30% (non-renal)+35% (adjusted renal function)=65%

Therefore, the adjusted dose rate should be 65% of the original dose:

60 mg/hour×0.65=39 mg/hour

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For drugs with significant renal clearance, dose adjustments are necessary when GFR is decreased.
  • Calculate the adjusted dose by considering both the non-renal elimination and the reduced renal elimination capacity.
  • In patients with 50% renal function, the new dose rate is adjusted proportionally when 70% of the drug's clearance is renal.

questions.text: Which clinical scenario would most likely warrant the use of this instrument?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Postpartum hemorrhage

 

  • The image shows a Bakri balloon, which is commonly used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), particularly when bleeding is due to uterine atony.
  • The balloon is inserted into the uterine cavity and inflated with sterile saline, creating pressure against the uterine walls to control bleeding.
  • This mechanical compression helps tamponade bleeding from the uterine surface, especially when medications like oxytocin are insufficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retained placenta: Management of retained placenta involves manual removal or surgical intervention rather than the use of a Bakri balloon. The instrument in the image does not aid in the extraction of retained placental tissue directly.

 

Option C. Uterine inversion: Uterine inversion is a rare but serious complication where the uterus turns inside out after childbirth. It requires immediate repositioning of the uterus, often manually or surgically. A Bakri balloon is not used in this scenario, as it does not help reposition the inverted uterus.

 

Option D. Uterine atony: Uterine atony refers to the failure of the uterus to contract adequately after delivery, leading to excessive bleeding. While a Bakri balloon can be used to control bleeding from uterine atony, it is specifically indicated when atony results in severe postpartum hemorrhage, making the broader indication of PPH more accurate in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Bakri balloon is a mechanical tamponade device used in the management of postpartum hemorrhage when uterine atony or other causes lead to significant bleeding that cannot be controlled with uterotonic agents alone.

choices.text: Deficiency of von Willebrand factor
Deficiency of glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a lifelong history of easy bruising and prolonged bleeding from minor cuts. Recently, he has experienced frequent nosebleeds and gum bleeding while brushing his teeth. Physical examination reveals petechiae on his lower extremities, but there is no hepatosplenomegaly. Laboratory tests reveal a normal platelet count, but the peripheral smear shows abnormally large platelets. Bleeding time is prolonged, while prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are within normal limits. Platelet aggregation studies show a poor response to ristocetin but normal aggregation in response to ADP and collagen. Given these findings, which molecular abnormality is most likely present in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Deficiency of glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex

 

  • This patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings are characteristic of Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a rare inherited platelet disorder.
  • The disease is caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, which is crucial for platelet adhesion to the vessel wall by binding to von Willebrand factor.
  • This defect results in impaired platelet aggregation in response to ristocetin, while aggregation in response to ADP and collagen remains normal.
  • The presence of abnormally large platelets and a normal platelet count, along with prolonged bleeding time, further supports the diagnosis of Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of glycoprotein IIb/IIIa: This describes Glanzmann thrombasthenia, which results in defective platelet aggregation in response to ADP, collagen, and other agonists. However, in this condition, platelets typically respond to ristocetin, unlike in Bernard-Soulier syndrome.

 

Option B. Deficiency of von Willebrand factor: This describes von Willebrand disease, which is characterized by a defect in platelet adhesion and may present with prolonged bleeding time and an abnormal response to ristocetin. However, it typically does not show abnormally large platelets on a smear or normal platelet counts with defective glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex.

 

Option D. Autoantibodies against platelets: This is associated with immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), which results in thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) rather than a defect in platelet aggregation. ITP would not result in the normal aggregation studies seen here except with ristocetin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bernard-Soulier syndrome is characterized by a deficiency of the glycoprotein Ib-IX-V complex, resulting in defective platelet adhesion, large platelets, and a poor aggregation response to ristocetin.
  • Recognizing the specific laboratory features helps differentiate it from other platelet disorders.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive dysphagia, predominantly for solid foods over the past 6 months. He also reports significant unintentional weight loss during this period. A barium swallow study is performed, and the radiographic image is shown below. Based on these clinical findings and the image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Esophageal carcinoma

 

  • The patient's presentation of progressive dysphagia, especially for solids, alongside significant unintentional weight loss, is highly suggestive of esophageal carcinoma.
  • The barium swallow image displays a narrowed segment with irregular contours, which is consistent with a malignant process.
  • Progressive dysphagia starting with difficulty swallowing solids before liquids is typical of an obstructive lesion, such as esophageal cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy compressing the esophagus: This condition can cause external pressure on the esophagus, leading to dysphagia. However, it is less likely to present with irregular intraluminal narrowing as seen in this case. Additionally, the clinical presentation here aligns more closely with an intrinsic malignant process rather than extrinsic compression.

 

Option B. Peptic stricture: Peptic strictures arise from chronic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and result in smooth, tapered narrowing of the esophagus. They typically do not present with significant weight loss, nor do they cause the irregular narrowing shown in the radiograph, which is more indicative of malignancy.

 

Option D. Esophageal web: Esophageal webs are thin, membranous structures within the esophagus that cause dysphagia, often affecting the proximal esophagus. They are not associated with significant weight loss and do not present with the irregular, constricting lesion seen in the barium swallow image of this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In patients presenting with progressive dysphagia, particularly when accompanied by unintentional weight loss, esophageal carcinoma should be considered as a likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Match the following regarding the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis (JE):
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2

 

Explanation:

 

  • Culex mosquitoes (A-4) act as the vector for the transmission of Japanese Encephalitis. They bite infected animals or birds and transmit the virus to humans and other animals.
  • Man (B-1) is considered an accidental host in the lifecycle of the Japanese Encephalitis virus because humans do not develop sufficient viremia to infect mosquitoes, thus playing no role in the maintenance of the virus.
  • Pigs (C-3) are considered the amplifier host because they develop a high viremia which helps to sustain and amplify the virus in the environment.
  • Ardeid birds (D-2) (such as herons and egrets) serve as the reservoir hosts for Japanese Encephalitis, where the virus can persist in the natural environment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

JE Epidemiology

 

  • Vector: Culex triteniorhynchus
  • Amplifier host: Pigs
  • Accidental host: Man
  • Reservoir host: Ardied birds (Herons, ducks, fowls)

questions.text: A 62-year-old male undergoes a colonoscopy as part of routine screening. During the procedure, a polyp is discovered and removed. Histological analysis of the polyp reveals the image below. Which of the following is the most accurate description for this type of polyp?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubulo-villous adenoma

 

  • Tubulo-villous adenomas have histological features that include a combination of tubular and villous structures, which is evident in the provided image.
  • This type of polyp has an intermediate risk of developing into colorectal cancer compared to purely tubular adenomas (lower risk) and villous adenomas (higher risk).
  • The mixed histological pattern seen here is characteristic of tubulo-villous adenoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tubular adenoma: Tubular adenomas consist primarily of tubular structures with a lower malignant potential than tubulo-villous adenomas. They do not have the mixture of villous structures seen in the provided image, making this option incorrect.

 

Option C. Hyperplastic polyp: Hyperplastic polyps are benign polyps with a serrated architecture and are typically not considered pre-malignant. They do not have the glandular or villous structures that characterize tubulo-villous adenomas, as seen in the histological image.

 

Option D. Villous adenoma: Villous adenomas have a higher proportion of villous structures and are associated with a higher risk of malignancy than tubulo-villous adenomas. While villous structures are present in the image, the mixture of both tubular and villous components is more consistent with a tubulo-villous adenoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubulo-villous adenomas are characterized by a mixture of tubular and villous structures, with an intermediate risk of progression to colorectal cancer compared to tubular adenomas and villous adenomas.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with acute pelvic pain and is diagnosed with an ectopic pregnancy. During a laparoscopic procedure, the following image is observed showing adhesions around the liver. What is the most likely underlying cause of this ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) History of pelvic infection

 

  • The image depicts adhesions near the liver, which can be suggestive of Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) that leads to adhesions between the liver and the peritoneum.
  • PID is a significant risk factor for developing ectopic pregnancy, as the inflammation and scarring from infection can lead to tubal damage, increasing the likelihood of an ectopic implantation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Previous abdominal surgery: Abdominal surgery can lead to adhesions, but it is not the most common cause in this scenario. Adhesions from surgery usually form around the site of operation and are not typically seen with Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, which is directly related to pelvic infection.

 

Option C. Malignancy: Malignancies do not typically cause the kind of adhesions shown in the image. While they can cause masses or changes in abdominal organs, they are not a common cause of ectopic pregnancies due to adhesions.

 

Option D. Endometriosis: Endometriosis can cause adhesions, but these typically present as chocolate cysts or patches of endometrial-like tissue in the pelvis. The adhesions in the liver area are more characteristic of PID-associated complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is a key risk factor for ectopic pregnancy due to the potential for tubal scarring and adhesions, which can impair the normal movement of the fertilized egg.

questions.text:
Identify the following instruments which are used for the measurement of the nutritional status of the child?

 

 

1. Harpenden caliper

2. Salters Scale

3. Shakir’s Tape

4. Infantometer
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-4, C-2, D-1

 

  • A - Shakir's Tape (A-3): Shakir's tape is a simple tool used to measure mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) in children. It helps in assessing malnutrition by measuring the circumference of the arm, which is an indicator of muscle mass and fat stores in children. It is particularly useful in community health settings for the early detection of malnutrition.
  • B - Infantometer (B-4): An infantometer is a device used to measure the length or height of infants who are below two years old. It is crucial for assessing linear growth and identifying stunting, which is a sign of chronic malnutrition.
  • C - Salter's Scale (C-2): Salter's scale is a portable weighing scale commonly used to measure the weight of infants and young children. It is used to assess weight-for-age, which is an important parameter in evaluating the nutritional status of a child.
  • D - Harpenden Caliper (D-1): A Harpenden caliper is used to measure skinfold thickness, which helps in estimating body fat percentage. It is particularly useful for assessing body composition and nutritional status in clinical and research settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different tools are used to measure various aspects of a child's nutritional status, such as body weight, height, arm circumference, and skinfold thickness.
  • Each tool has a specific purpose and is essential for the comprehensive assessment of growth and nutrition in children.
  • Understanding the correct usage of these tools helps in the early detection and management of malnutrition.

questions.text: Match the mode of inheritance with the corresponding disorder in the appropriate column:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-A

 

  • 1-B: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. A single copy of the mutant gene from an affected parent can lead to the condition.
  • 2-C: Hemophilia A follows an X-linked recessive inheritance pattern, typically affecting males as they have only one X chromosome inherited from their mother.
  • 3-D: Cystic fibrosis is an autosomal recessive disorder, meaning that two copies of the mutated gene (one from each parent) are necessary for the condition to manifest.
  • 4-A: Leber's disease is a mitochondrially inherited condition, which means it is passed down through the mitochondria present in the egg cell, hence inherited from the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman in her first pregnancy is identified as having a high risk of fetal Down syndrome based on her age. She seeks a screening test with the highest possible detection rate for chromosomal abnormalities. Which of the following would be the most appropriate recommendation for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cell-free DNA testing

 

  • Cell-free DNA testing (cfDNA) is a non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) method that analyzes small fragments of fetal DNA circulating in the maternal blood.
  • It has a high detection rate for Down syndrome, approaching 99% sensitivity and specificity, making it the ideal choice for screening in high-risk pregnancies, such as those associated with advanced maternal age.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chorionic villous sampling (CVS): This is an invasive diagnostic procedure that carries a risk of miscarriage. While it provides definitive diagnostic results, it is not considered a first-line screening test.

 

Option C. Quadruple screening test: The quadruple test is performed in the second trimester and assesses the levels of four serum markers to estimate the risk of Down syndrome. Its detection rate is lower than that of cfDNA testing, making it less suitable in high-risk cases.

 

Option D. Nuchal translucency scan: Nuchal translucency measurement is part of the first-trimester screening but is not as comprehensive as cfDNA testing. While it can help identify chromosomal abnormalities, it is less accurate than cfDNA testing when used alone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cell-free DNA testing is recommended for high-risk pregnancies due to its superior accuracy and non-invasive nature compared to other screening methods.

questions.text: 65-year-old woman is evaluated during a routine check-up. She reports feeling well overall, with no significant symptoms other than mild fatigue. Physical examination is unremarkable. Routine laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin level of 12.5 g/dL, calcium level of 9.2 mg/dL, and serum creatinine of 1.0 mg/dL. Serum protein electrophoresis identifies a monoclonal spike (M-spike) with an IgG concentration of 1.2 g/dL. Urine protein electrophoresis is negative for Bence Jones proteins. Bone marrow biopsy shows plasma cells comprising less than 10% of the total cellularity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)

 

  • MGUS is characterized by the presence of a monoclonal protein (M-protein) in the blood without the signs and symptoms of multiple myeloma or other related disorders.
  • The diagnostic criteria for MGUS include an M-spike of less than 3 g/dL, bone marrow plasma cells comprising less than 10% of cellularity, and the absence of CRAB (hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, or bone lesions) features.
  • The patient's findings, including a small M-spike, normal calcium and renal function, and plasma cells less than 10% on bone marrow biopsy, are consistent with MGUS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma: Characterized by a higher M-spike, bone marrow plasma cells greater than 10%, and the presence of CRAB features. This patient does not meet these criteria.

 

Option B. Waldenström macroglobulinemia: Typically involves an IgM monoclonal protein and presents with symptoms related to hyperviscosity, such as vision changes or neurologic symptoms, which are not seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Primary amyloidosis: Associated with organ involvement due to amyloid deposits, which is not evident in this patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MGUS is an asymptomatic condition identified by the presence of a monoclonal protein in the blood, with a low M-spike, fewer than 10% plasma cells in the bone marrow, and no evidence of organ damage or other features of multiple myeloma.

choices.text: A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1
A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3
A-2, B-3, C-1, D-4

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A-3, B-2, C-4, D-1

 

Explanation:

 

  • A. Borderline Personality Disorder - 3. Unstable relationships and fear of abandonment
    • Individuals with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) often experience intense fears of abandonment, unstable interpersonal relationships, and rapid mood shifts.
  • B. Antisocial Personality Disorder - 2. Lack of empathy and exploitation of others
    • Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others, a lack of empathy, and often manipulative or exploitative behavior.
  • C. Narcissistic Personality Disorder - 4. Grandiose sense of self-importance
    • Individuals with Narcissistic Personality Disorder tend to have an inflated sense of their own importance and a need for admiration, often coupled with a lack of empathy for others.
  • D. Schizoid Personality Disorder - 1. Preference for solitary activities
    • People with Schizoid Personality Disorder tend to be socially detached, preferring solitary activities and displaying little interest in forming close relationships.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl presents with her mother, who is concerned about her child experiencing intense perianal itching, particularly at night. On further questioning, the mother also reports that her daughter is having difficulty sleeping and is being irritable. A stool sample examination was performed, and the egg was seen in the picture below. Which of the following is the most likely organism responsible for this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Enterobius vermicularis

 

  • The image shows an elongated egg with a flattened side and a thick shell, characteristic of Enterobius vermicularis, commonly known as pinworm.
  • Enterobius vermicularis eggs are laid around the perianal region, causing intense perianal itching, especially at night when the female worm emerges to deposit eggs.
  • The itching often leads to difficulty sleeping, and in some cases, secondary bacterial infection due to scratching.
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed by identifying eggs either in the stool or using the Scotch tape test to collect eggs from the perianal region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Trichuris trichiura: Also known as whipworm, these eggs are barrel-shaped with bipolar plugs at each end.

 

 

Option C. Ascaris lumbricoides: Ascaris eggs are round or oval with a rough, thick shell and lack the characteristic flattened side seen in Enterobius eggs.

 

 

Option D. Necator americanus: This is a type of hookworm, and its eggs are oval with visible blastomeres, but they do not have the flattened side as seen in Enterobius eggs.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enterobius vermicularis (pinworm) causes perianal itching, particularly at night.
  • The eggs are elongated with a flattened side, and diagnosis can be made through stool microscopy or the Scotch tape test.

choices.text: Obtain a skeletal survey to evaluate for multiple myeloma
Perform a breast ultrasound to screen for metastatic disease
Perform a parathyroid scintigraphy scan (Sestamibi scan)

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the clinic with diffuse bone pain, primarily affecting her right arm and left thigh. She also reports worsening constipation and mild fatigue. On physical examination, there is tenderness over the left thigh. Laboratory tests reveal a serum calcium level of 13.2 mg/dL, phosphate level of 1.3 mg/dL, and creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Additional laboratory findings include an elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) level. A bone biopsy reveals cystic changes, fibrosis, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages. An X-ray of the left femur demonstrates subperiosteal bone resorption. Based on these findings, what is the most appropriate initial intervention to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Perform a parathyroid scintigraphy scan (Sestamibi scan)

 

  • The patient's presentation, laboratory findings, and imaging studies strongly suggest primary hyperparathyroidism, most likely due to a parathyroid adenoma.
  • Hypercalcemia, hypophosphatemia, and elevated PTH levels are hallmarks of this condition.
  • The bone biopsy showing cystic changes, fibrosis, and hemosiderin-laden macrophages is indicative of osteitis fibrosa cystica, a skeletal manifestation of severe hyperparathyroidism.
  • Subperiosteal bone resorption on X-ray is another classic finding.
  • The most appropriate next step is to localize the source of excessive PTH secretion, typically a parathyroid adenoma, using a parathyroid scintigraphy (Sestamibi scan) for surgical planning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measure serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D levels: While vitamin D deficiency can exacerbate hyperparathyroidism, the constellation of symptoms and lab findings here (marked hypercalcemia, bone resorption) points directly to primary hyperparathyroidism rather than a simple vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Obtain a skeletal survey to evaluate for multiple myeloma: Multiple myeloma can cause bone pain and hypercalcemia, but it usually presents with other features like anemia, elevated creatinine, and characteristic lytic bone lesions. The patient's bone biopsy findings and subperiosteal bone resorption are more consistent with primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Option C. Perform a breast ultrasound to screen for metastatic disease: Hypercalcemia can occur in metastatic breast cancer; however, this patient's specific skeletal findings (subperiosteal resorption and cystic bone lesions) are more typical of hyperparathyroidism. Additionally, there are no clinical signs pointing to a primary breast malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism is a common cause of hypercalcemia with characteristic skeletal manifestations, including osteitis fibrosa cystica and subperiosteal bone resorption.
  • The most definitive diagnostic step involves localization of a parathyroid adenoma, typically through parathyroid scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman with a history of osteoporosis presents to her physician to discuss treatment options. She has already tried bisphosphonates, but they caused severe gastrointestinal discomfort. The physician considers a medication that directly stimulates osteoblast activity to promote bone formation. Which of the following drugs is most appropriate for this purpose?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Teriparatide

 

  • Teriparatide is a recombinant form of parathyroid hormone (PTH) that directly stimulates osteoblast activity, leading to increased bone formation.
  • It is specifically used in patients with severe osteoporosis who are at high risk for fractures and in those who may not tolerate other therapies.
  •  Abaloparatide is another drug in the same class that also stimulates osteoblasts.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Denosumab: This drug is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits osteoclast activity by targeting RANKL, leading to decreased bone resorption. It does not directly stimulate osteoblasts.

 

Option C. Raloxifene: Raloxifene is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that inhibits osteoclast activity, reducing bone resorption. It is used to prevent bone loss but does not stimulate osteoblasts.

 

Option D. Calcitonin: Calcitonin works by inhibiting osteoclasts, reducing bone resorption and decreasing calcium levels. It is not used for stimulating osteoblast activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN OSTEOPOROSIS

choices.text: Anconeus is supplied by a branch arising in the axilla.
The lateral head of the triceps is paralyzed in a lesion of the radial nerve in the lower spiral groove.
It leaves the axilla by passing through the quadrangular space.
In the arm, it travels along the brachial artery.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand after a humeral shaft fracture, suggesting a radial nerve injury. Which of the following statements about the radial nerve is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The lateral head of the triceps is paralyzed in a lesion of the radial nerve in the lower spiral groove.

 

  • The radial nerve runs along the spiral groove of the humerus and supplies the triceps brachii muscle.
  • In a mid-shaft humeral fracture, the radial nerve may be injured, affecting the lateral head of the triceps.
  • This can result in weakness or paralysis of the lateral head along with wrist drop and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anconeus is supplied by a branch arising in the axilla: This statement is incorrect. The anconeus muscle is innervated by a branch of the radial nerve that arises in the arm, not the axilla.

 

Option C. It leaves the axilla by passing through the quadrangular space: This is incorrect. The axillary nerve, not the radial nerve, exits the axilla through the quadrangular space. The radial nerve exits the axilla via the triangular interval and enters the posterior compartment of the arm.

 

Option D. In the arm, it travels along the brachial artery: This is incorrect. The radial nerve travels with the deep brachial artery in the posterior compartment, not along the main brachial artery, which is found in the anterior compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The radial nerve runs along the spiral groove of the humerus and can be injured in mid-shaft humeral fractures.
  • Lesions in this area can cause paralysis of the lateral head of the triceps and wrist drop.

choices.text: To check the depth of anesthesia
To see if there was bradycardia
To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is undergoing surgery to correct a congenital ptosis. The induction of anesthesia is smooth, and the procedure proceeds without complications. As the surgeon begins to manipulate the extraocular muscles, the anesthesiologist looks at the monitor. Why is the anesthesiologist doing this?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) To see if there was bradycardia

 

  • The anesthesiologist monitors the cardiac rhythm closely during manipulation of the extraocular muscles to detect the oculocardiac reflex.
  • This reflex is a trigemino-vagal reflex where afferent signals are carried by the trigeminal nerve and efferent signals by the vagus nerve.
  • It is triggered when traction is applied to the extraocular muscles, especially during surgeries involving these muscles, like strabismus or ptosis correction.
  • The reflex can cause bradycardia (most common), asystole, or other types of arrhythmias due to increased parasympathetic activity.
  • Awareness of this potential complication allows the anesthesiologist to respond quickly, usually by ceasing manipulation of the muscle or administering antimuscarinic agents like atropine or glycopyrrolate to counteract the bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To check the depth of anesthesia: While depth of anesthesia is important, it is not specifically related to the need for monitoring the heart rate during eye muscle manipulation. The concern here is primarily the oculocardiac reflex.

 

Option B. To look for hypotension: Hypotension is not directly related to the manipulation of the extraocular muscles or the triggering of the oculocardiac reflex. Bradycardia is the primary manifestation of this reflex.

 

Option D. To ensure there were no ventricular arrhythmias: While arrhythmias can occur as a result of the oculocardiac reflex, the initial concern during eye muscle manipulation is bradycardia due to the reflex arc involving the trigeminal and vagus nerves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The oculocardiac reflex is a common occurrence during eye surgeries involving manipulation of the extraocular muscles, leading to bradycardia through the trigemino-vagal pathway.
  • Awareness and prompt management are crucial to avoid severe complications during these procedures.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with progressive muscle weakness and difficulty swallowing over the past 6 months. He also reports episodes of choking while eating and frequent coughing, particularly at night. On examination, there is spasticity in the lower limbs, hyperreflexia, and fasciculations in the tongue and arms. His speech is slurred, and there is notable muscle atrophy in the hands. Over time, his symptoms worsen, and he develops respiratory difficulty. Which of the following medications could slow the progression of his disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Riluzole

 

  • The patient's symptoms, including progressive muscle weakness, dysphagia, spasticity, fasciculations, and muscle atrophy, are characteristic of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS).
  • ALS is a neurodegenerative disease that affects both upper and lower motor neurons.
  • Riluzole is the only medication approved to slow the progression of ALS.
  • It works by inhibiting glutamate release, which reduces excitotoxic damage to neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Glatiramer acetate: An immunomodulator used in multiple sclerosis (MS). It has no therapeutic effect in ALS.

 

Option B. Corticosteroids: Used in inflammatory conditions, such as autoimmune diseases, but they do not impact the progression of ALS, which is a neurodegenerative disease.

 

Option C. Inactivated virus vaccine: Vaccines are preventative measures against infections and do not have a role in treating neurodegenerative conditions like ALS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Riluzole is an approved medication that can slow the progression of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) by reducing glutamate-induced neuronal damage.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is diagnosed with congenital glaucoma and needs to start medical treatment. Which of the following antiglaucoma medications is considered unsafe for use in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brimonidine

 

  • Brimonidine is an alpha-2 adrenergic agonist used in the treatment of glaucoma to reduce intraocular pressure.
  •  However, it is contraindicated in infants due to the risk of central nervous system depression, including apnea, bradycardia, and lethargy.
  •  Therefore, it is considered unsafe in pediatric patients, particularly those under the age of two years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: Timolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used to lower intraocular pressure in glaucoma. While it can be used cautiously in pediatric patients, it may require monitoring for potential side effects like bradycardia and bronchospasm.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin analog that increases the outflow of aqueous humor. It is generally considered safe for use in children and is often prescribed in pediatric glaucoma management.

 

Option D. Dorzolamide: Dorzolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor used to reduce intraocular pressure. It can be used in pediatric patients, and its side effects are generally mild, including ocular irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Brimonidine is unsafe for infants due to the risk of serious central nervous system side effects.
  • Other medications like timolol, latanoprost, and dorzolamide can be used cautiously in pediatric patients with appropriate monitoring.

questions.text: A 11-year-old boy presents to the clinic with small, raised, rough lesions on his hands and fingers. His mother reports that the lesions have been slowly increasing in number over the past several months. The child is otherwise healthy with no history of significant illness. On examination, the lesions are firm with a rough surface. What types of human papillomavirus (HPV) are most commonly associated with these cutaneous lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) HPV 2, 4, 27

 

  • These types of human papillomavirus (HPV) are most commonly associated with cutaneous warts, particularly common warts (verrucae vulgaris), which are often found on the hands and fingers in children.
  • Common warts are firm, rough, and raised, which matches the description of the lesions in this patient.
  • HPV 2, 4, and 27 are responsible for the majority of these benign skin lesions, which are transmitted through direct contact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV 7: HPV 7 is associated with a specific form of warts known as butcher’s warts, typically seen in individuals who handle meat, poultry, or fish. This HPV type is less common and is not typically implicated in warts seen in the general population, particularly in children with no occupational exposure.

 

Option B. HPV 16, 18: HPV types 16 and 18 are associated with anogenital warts and are high-risk types for the development of cervical and other anogenital cancers. These types of HPV are not associated with cutaneous warts on the hands and fingers, but instead cause lesions on mucosal surfaces. Hence, this option is incorrect for the scenario described.

 

Option C. HPV 6, 11: HPV types 6 and 11 are most commonly linked with anogenital warts (condyloma acuminata) and low-risk for malignancy. These types may also cause respiratory papillomatosis but are not responsible for common cutaneous warts, making this option incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Human papillomavirus types 2, 4, and 27 are the most common causes of cutaneous warts (verrucae vulgaris), especially on the hands and fingers.
  • These warts are firm, raised, and rough-surfaced, and are often seen in children due to direct contact transmission of HPV.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Salter scale

 

  • The instrument shown is a Salter scale. It is a mechanical device used specifically for weighing infants and young children, particularly those aged 1-5 years.
  • The child is placed in a sling that is then attached to the scale, allowing for a weight measurement when suspended.
  • The Salter scale is widely used in various health programs, including those sponsored by UNICEF, especially in remote or resource-limited settings.
  • It aids in monitoring the growth and development of children by providing accurate weight measurements.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spring balance: This instrument measures weight based on the tension of a spring, but it is not typically used for weighing infants in healthcare settings.

 

Option B. Beam balance: A beam balance is used for precise weight measurements in laboratories or for educational purposes but is not practical for weighing children.

 

Option C. Electronic weighing scale: This is a common tool for weighing patients, but it is usually used for older children or adults. It requires a flat surface and electricity or batteries, unlike the Salter scale, which can be used in field settings without electricity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Salter scale is a key instrument for measuring the weight of infants in field settings, often used by healthcare workers and programs like UNICEF for growth monitoring and nutritional assessments.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents with visual disturbances affecting the central field of vision. An MRI of the brain is performed, revealing the involvement of a specific sulcus in the occipital lobe, as indicated by the arrow in the provided image. Which of the following sulci is identified in the given coronal section?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcarine sulcus

 

  • The calcarine sulcus is a prominent sulcus located in the occipital lobe, extending from the parieto-occipital sulcus to the posterior pole of the brain.
  • It plays a crucial role in the primary visual cortex (V1), which is responsible for processing visual information, including central vision.
  • In this MRI, the arrow points to a location consistent with the calcarine sulcus, making this the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Marginal sulcus: The marginal sulcus is part of the cingulate sulcus that extends to the medial aspect of the brain. It is not involved in the visual processing of central vision and is located more anteriorly compared to the calcarine sulcus.

 

Option C. Parieto-occipital sulcus: This sulcus separates the parietal and occipital lobes but is not directly involved in the processing of visual information in the primary visual cortex. It is located more anteriorly relative to the calcarine sulcus.

 

Option D. Lingual sulcus: The lingual sulcus is related to the lingual gyrus, which is also involved in visual processing but is not the primary visual cortex like the calcarine sulcus. The sulcus identified in the image is more consistent with the location of the calcarine sulcus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The calcarine sulcus is located in the occipital lobe and is integral to the function of the primary visual cortex.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a 20-year history of poorly controlled type 1 diabetes presents with blurred vision and is found to have a developing cataract. Which of the following enzymes is most closely linked to the underlying mechanism in this patient's cataract condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aldose reductase

 

  • Aldose reductase is the key enzyme involved in the conversion of glucose to sorbitol, particularly in tissues where glucose uptake is insulin-independent, such as the lens, retina, and peripheral nerves.
  • In patients with long-standing diabetes, high blood glucose levels lead to an increased flux of glucose through the polyol pathway.
  • Aldose reductase reduces glucose to sorbitol.
  • Since sorbitol is a sugar alcohol that accumulates in tissues with low levels of sorbitol dehydrogenase, it causes osmotic stress, leading to water accumulation in the lens, resulting in cataract formation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sorbitol dehydrogenase: While sorbitol dehydrogenase converts sorbitol into fructose, it is not the primary enzyme involved in the initial accumulation of sorbitol in the lens. The lens has relatively low sorbitol dehydrogenase activity, which contributes to sorbitol build-up when glucose is converted to sorbitol by aldose reductase.

 

Option C. Glucokinase: Glucokinase is involved in the conversion of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate in the liver and pancreatic beta cells. It is not related to the polyol pathway or the development of diabetic cataracts.

 

Option D. Hexokinase: Hexokinase is responsible for the phosphorylation of glucose to glucose-6-phosphate in most tissues. It is not directly involved in the conversion of glucose to sorbitol, which is mediated by aldose reductase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aldose reductase plays a crucial role in the conversion of glucose to sorbitol in the polyol pathway, especially under hyperglycemic conditions.
  • In patients with diabetes, the accumulation of sorbitol in tissues with limited sorbitol dehydrogenase activity can lead to osmotic stress, contributing to complications like cataract formation in the lens.
